<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Catholic Church</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Largest Christian church, led by the pope</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Catholic" and "Roman Catholic Church" redirect here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_(disambiguation)" title="Catholic Church (disambiguation)">Catholic Church (disambiguation)</a>, <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Catholic_(disambiguation)" title="Catholic (disambiguation)">Catholic (disambiguation)</a>, and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church_(disambiguation)" title="Roman Catholic Church (disambiguation)">Roman Catholic Church (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

</div><div class="hlist hlist-separated">

<ul><li><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg" title="Christian cross"><img alt="Christian cross" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="18" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/20px-P_christianity.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/30px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/40px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" width="20"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Christianity_sidebar" title="Template:Christianity sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Christianity_sidebar" title="Template talk:Christianity sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Christianity_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <b>Catholic Church</b>, also known as the <b>Roman Catholic Church</b>, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations_by_number_of_members" title="List of Christian denominations by number of members">largest Christian church</a>, with 1.3 billion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baptised" title="Baptised">baptised</a> Catholics <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">worldwide</a> as of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnnuarioPontificio_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-AnnuarioPontificio-4">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> As the world's oldest and largest continuously functioning international institution,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> it has played a prominent role in the history and development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_civilisation" title="Western civilisation">Western civilisation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O'CollinsPref_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-O'CollinsPref-9">[9]</a></sup> The church consists of 24 <a href="/wiki/Catholic_particular_churches_and_liturgical_rites#Churches" title="Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites">particular churches</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a> and 23 <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a>, as well as almost 3,500 <a href="/wiki/Diocese" title="Diocese">dioceses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eparchy" title="Eparchy">eparchies</a> located <a href="/wiki/List_of_Catholic_dioceses_(structured_view)" title="List of Catholic dioceses (structured view)">around the world</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">pope</a>, who is the bishop of Rome, is the <a href="/wiki/Papal_supremacy" title="Papal supremacy">chief pastor</a> of the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The bishopric of Rome, known as the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, is the central governing authority of the church. The administrative body of the Holy See, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Curia" title="Roman Curia">Roman Curia</a>, has its principal offices in <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a>, a small enclave of the Italian city of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rome,_Italy" title="Rome, Italy">Rome</a>, of which the pope is <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>.
</p><p>The core beliefs of Catholicism are found in the <a href="/wiki/Nicene_Creed" title="Nicene Creed">Nicene Creed</a>. The Catholic Church teaches that it is the <a href="/wiki/Four_Marks_of_the_Church" title="Four Marks of the Church">one, holy, catholic and apostolic</a> church founded by <a href="/wiki/Jesus_in_Christianity" title="Jesus in Christianity">Jesus Christ</a> in his <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_News_Service-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter20047_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter20047-12">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[note 1]</a></sup> that its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bishop_(Catholic_Church)" title="Bishop (Catholic Church)">bishops</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">successors</a> of Christ's <a href="/wiki/Apostles_in_the_New_Testament" title="Apostles in the New Testament">apostles</a>, and that the pope is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Successor_to_Saint_Peter" title="Successor to Saint Peter">successor</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>, upon whom <a href="/wiki/Primacy_of_Peter" title="Primacy of Peter">primacy</a> was conferred by Jesus Christ.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup> It maintains that it practises the original Christian faith taught by the apostles, preserving the faith <a href="/wiki/Infallibility_of_the_Church" title="Infallibility of the Church">infallibly</a> through <a href="/wiki/Biblical_canon" title="Biblical canon">scripture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sacred_tradition" title="Sacred tradition">sacred tradition</a> as authentically interpreted through the <a href="/wiki/Magisterium" title="Magisterium">magisterium</a> of the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCC_890_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCC_890-17">[16]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Latin_liturgical_rites" title="Latin liturgical rites">others</a> of the Latin Church, the <a href="/wiki/Christian_liturgy#Eastern_Christian_churches" title="Christian liturgy">Eastern Christian rites</a> of the Eastern Catholic Churches, and institutes such as <a href="/wiki/Mendicant_orders" title="Mendicant orders">mendicant orders</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enclosed_religious_orders" title="Enclosed religious orders">enclosed monastic orders</a> and <a href="/wiki/Third_order" title="Third order">third orders</a> reflect a <a href="/wiki/Catholic_particular_churches_and_liturgical_rites" title="Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites">variety</a> of <a href="/wiki/Theology" title="Theology">theological</a> and spiritual emphases in the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gunton2_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gunton2-19">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Of its <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">seven sacraments</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Eucharist in the Catholic Church">Eucharist</a> is the principal one, celebrated <a href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgy" title="Catholic liturgy">liturgically</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mass_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Mass in the Catholic Church">Mass</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[19]</a></sup> The church teaches that through <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Eucharist" title="Consecration">consecration</a> by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Priesthood_(Catholic_Church)" title="Priesthood (Catholic Church)">priest</a>, the sacrificial <a href="/wiki/Sacramental_bread" title="Sacramental bread">bread</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sacramental_wine" title="Sacramental wine">wine</a> become the <a href="/wiki/Transubstantiation" title="Transubstantiation">body and blood of Christ</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Virgin_Mary" title="Virgin Mary">Virgin Mary</a> is <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">venerated</a> as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perpetual_Virgin" title="Perpetual Virgin">Perpetual Virgin</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mother_of_God" title="Mother of God">Mother of God</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Heaven" title="Queen of Heaven">Queen of Heaven</a>; she is honoured in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_Catholic_Church#Dogmatic_teachings" title="Mariology of the Catholic Church">dogmas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marian_devotions" title="Marian devotions">devotions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-marian_dogmas_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-marian_dogmas-21">[20]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching" title="Catholic social teaching">Catholic social teaching</a> emphasises voluntary support for the sick, the poor, and the afflicted through the <a href="/wiki/Works_of_mercy" title="Works of mercy">corporal and spiritual works of mercy</a>. The Catholic Church operates thousands of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_school" title="Catholic school">Catholic schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_higher_education" title="Catholic higher education">universities and colleges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_health_care" title="Catholic Church and health care">hospitals</a>, and orphanages around the world, and is the largest non-government provider of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_education" title="Catholic education">education</a> and health care in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geopolitics_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-Geopolitics-22">[21]</a></sup> Among its other social services are numerous charitable and humanitarian organisations.
</p><p>The Catholic Church has profoundly influenced <a href="/wiki/Western_philosophy" title="Western philosophy">Western philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">culture</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_art" title="Western art">art</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_classical_music" title="Western classical music">music</a> and science. Catholics live all over the world through <a href="/wiki/Catholic_missions" title="Catholic missions">missions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diaspora" title="Diaspora">diaspora</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Conversion_to_Christianity" title="Conversion to Christianity">conversions</a>. Since the 20th century, the majority have resided in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southern_hemisphere" title="Southern hemisphere">southern hemisphere</a>, partially due to <a href="/wiki/Postchristianity" title="Postchristianity">secularisation</a> in Europe and increased <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians" title="Persecution of Christians">persecution</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>. The Catholic Church shared <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">communion</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> until the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> in 1054, disputing particularly the <a href="/wiki/Papal_supremacy" title="Papal supremacy">authority of the pope</a>. Before the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ephesus" title="Council of Ephesus">Council of Ephesus</a> in AD 431, the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_East" title="Church of the East">Church of the East</a> also shared in this communion, as did the <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox_Churches" title="Oriental Orthodox Churches">Oriental Orthodox Churches</a> before the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> in AD 451; all separated primarily over <a href="/wiki/Chalcedonian_Definition" title="Chalcedonian Definition">differences in</a> <a href="/wiki/Christology" title="Christology">Christology</a>. The Eastern Catholic Churches, who have a combined membership of approximately 18 million, represent a body of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christians</a> who returned or remained in communion with the pope during or following these <a href="/wiki/Schism_in_Christianity" title="Schism in Christianity">schisms</a> for a variety of historical circumstances. In the 16th century, the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> led to <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> also breaking away.  From the late 20th century, the Catholic Church has been <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Criticism of the Catholic Church">criticised</a> for its <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology_of_sexuality" title="Catholic theology of sexuality">teachings on sexuality</a>, its <a href="/wiki/Ordination_of_women_and_the_Catholic_Church" title="Ordination of women and the Catholic Church">doctrine against ordaining women</a>, and its handling of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_sexual_abuse_cases" title="Catholic Church sexual abuse cases">sexual abuse cases</a> involving clergy.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_(term)" title="Catholic (term)">Catholic (term)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_(term)" title="Roman Catholic (term)">Roman Catholic (term)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ignatius_of_Antiochie,_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_(17th_c.,_Pushkin_museum).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="1129" decoding="async" height="292" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg/220px-Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg/330px-Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg/440px-Ignatius_of_Antiochie%2C_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_%2817th_c.%2C_Pushkin_museum%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ignatius_of_Antiochie,_poss._by_Johann_Apakass_(17th_c.,_Pushkin_museum).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The first use of the term "Catholic Church" (literally meaning "universal church") was by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Church_father" title="Church father">church father</a> Saint <a href="/wiki/Ignatius_of_Antioch" title="Ignatius of Antioch">Ignatius of Antioch</a> in his <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Letter_to_the_Smyrnaeans" title="Letter to the Smyrnaeans">Letter to the Smyrnaeans</a></i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 110</span> AD).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[22]</a></sup> Ignatius of Antioch is also attributed the earliest recorded use of the term "Christianity" (Greek: <span lang="el">Χριστιανισμός</span>) <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 100</span> AD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[23]</a></sup> He died in Rome, with his <a href="/wiki/Relic" title="Relic">relics</a> located in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basilica_of_San_Clemente_al_Laterano" title="Basilica of San Clemente al Laterano">Basilica of San Clemente al Laterano</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Catholic (from <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">καθολικός</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek" title="Romanization of Greek">romanized</a>: </small><span title="Greek-language romanization"><i lang="el-Latn">katholikos</i></span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a> </small>'universal') was first used to describe the church in the early 2nd century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[24]</a></sup> The first known use of the phrase "the catholic church" (<a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">καθολικὴ ἐκκλησία</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek" title="Romanization of Greek">romanized</a>: </small><span title="Greek-language romanization"><i lang="el-Latn">he katholike ekklesia</i></span>) occurred in the letter written about 110 AD from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Ignatius_of_Antioch" title="Saint Ignatius of Antioch">Saint Ignatius of Antioch</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Smyrna" title="Smyrna">Smyrnaeans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[note 2]</a></sup> In the <i>Catechetical Lectures</i> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 350</span>) of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Cyril_of_Jerusalem" title="Saint Cyril of Jerusalem">Saint Cyril of Jerusalem</a>, the name "Catholic Church" was used to distinguish it from other groups that also called themselves "the church".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CathEnc1910_Catholic_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-CathEnc1910_Catholic-26">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup> The "Catholic" notion was further stressed in the edict <i><a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Thessalonica" title="Edict of Thessalonica">De fide Catolica</a></i> issued 380 by <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a>, the last emperor to rule over both the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" title="Eastern Roman Empire">eastern</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">western</a> halves of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, when establishing the <a href="/wiki/State_church_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="State church of the Roman Empire">state church of the Roman Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> of 1054, the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Church</a> has taken the adjective "Orthodox" as its distinctive epithet (however, its official name continues to be the "Orthodox Catholic Church"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[28]</a></sup>) and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_Church" title="Western Church">Western Church</a> in communion with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> has similarly taken "Catholic", keeping that description also after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> of the 16th century, when those who ceased to be in communion became known as "Protestants".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McBrien_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-McBrien-32">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>While the "Roman Church" has been used to describe the pope's <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_Rome" title="Diocese of Rome">Diocese of Rome</a> since the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire" title="Fall of the Western Roman Empire">Fall of the Western Roman Empire</a> and into the <a href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Ages" title="Early Middle Ages">Early Middle Ages</a> (6th–10th century), the "Roman Catholic Church" has been applied to the whole church in the English language since the Protestant Reformation in the late 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[31]</a></sup> Further, some will refer to the Latin Church as "Roman Catholic" in distinction from the Eastern Catholic churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[32]</a></sup> "Roman Catholic" has occasionally appeared also in documents produced both by the Holy See,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RCHolySeeR_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-RCHolySeeR-35">[note 3]</a></sup> and notably used by certain national <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_conference" title="Episcopal conference">episcopal conferences</a> and local dioceses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RCbishop_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-RCbishop-36">[note 4]</a></sup>
</p><p>The name "Catholic Church" for the whole church is used in the <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i> (1990) and the <a href="/wiki/1983_Code_of_Canon_Law" title="1983 Code of Canon Law">Code of Canon Law</a> (1983). The name "Catholic Church" is also used in the documents of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> (1962–1965),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[33]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/First_Vatican_Council" title="First Vatican Council">First Vatican Council</a> (1869–1870),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[34]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> (1545–1563),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[35]</a></sup> and numerous other official documents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[37]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="History of the Catholic Church">History of the Catholic Church</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Timeline of the Catholic Church">Timeline of the Catholic Church</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Historiography_of_early_Christianity" title="Historiography of early Christianity">Historiography of early Christianity</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_(Capilla_Sixtina,_1481-82).jpg"><img alt="Painting a haloed Jesus Christ passing keys to a kneeling man." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1893" data-file-width="3055" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg/280px-Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg/420px-Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg/560px-Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_%28Capilla_Sixtina%2C_1481-82%29.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Perugino_-_Entrega_de_las_llaves_a_San_Pedro_(Capilla_Sixtina,_1481-82).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>This <a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">fresco</a> (1481–82) by <a href="/wiki/Pietro_Perugino" title="Pietro Perugino">Pietro Perugino</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Sistine_Chapel" title="Sistine Chapel">Sistine Chapel</a> shows Jesus giving the <a href="/wiki/Keys_of_Heaven" title="Keys of Heaven">keys of heaven</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Christian religion is based on the reported teachings of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>, who lived and preached in the 1st century AD in the province of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judea_(Roman_province)" title="Judea (Roman province)">Judea</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology" title="Catholic theology">Catholic theology</a> teaches that the contemporary Catholic Church is the continuation of this early Christian community established by Jesus <a href="/wiki/Christ_(title)" title="Christ (title)">Christ</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_News_Service-11">[11]</a></sup> Christianity spread throughout the early Roman Empire, despite persecutions due to conflicts with the pagan state religion. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_Constantine" title="Emperor Constantine">Emperor Constantine</a> legalised the practice of Christianity in 313, and it became the state religion in 380. Germanic invaders of Roman territory in the 5th and 6th centuries, many of whom had previously adopted <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arian_Christianity" title="Arian Christianity">Arian Christianity</a>, eventually adopted Catholicism to ally themselves with the papacy and the monasteries.
</p><p>In the 7th and 8th centuries, expanding <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests" title="Muslim conquests">Muslim conquests</a> following the advent of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> led to an Arab domination of the Mediterranean that severed political connections between that area and northern Europe, and weakened cultural connections between Rome and the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_opposition_to_papal_supremacy" title="Eastern Orthodox opposition to papal supremacy">Conflicts involving authority in the church</a>, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_differences_between_the_Catholic_Church_and_the_Eastern_Orthodox_Church#Papal_authority" title="Ecclesiastical differences between the Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church">authority of the bishop of Rome</a> finally culminated in the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> in the 11th century, splitting the church into the Catholic and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> churches. Earlier splits within the church occurred after the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Ephesus" title="Council of Ephesus">Council of Ephesus</a> (431) and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> (451). However, a few Eastern Churches remained in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communion_(Christian)" title="Communion (Christian)">communion</a> with Rome, and portions of some others established communion in the 15th century and later, forming what are called the Eastern Catholic Churches.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2926" data-file-width="5193" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg/350px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg/525px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg/700px-%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C3%9Altima_Cena_-_Da_Vinci_5.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Last_Supper_(Leonardo_da_Vinci)" title="The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)"><i>The Last Supper</i></a>, a late 1490s mural painting by <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>, depicting the last supper of Jesus and his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelve_apostles" title="Twelve apostles">twelve apostles</a> on the eve of his <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion" title="Crucifixion">crucifixion</a>. Most apostles are buried in Rome, including Saint Peter.</div></div></div>
<p>Early monasteries throughout Europe helped preserve Greek and Roman <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Classical_civilisation" title="Classical civilisation">classical civilisation</a>. The church eventually became the dominant influence in Western civilisation into the modern age. Many <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> figures were sponsored by the church. The 16th century, however, began to see challenges to the church, in particular to its religious authority, by <a href="/wiki/List_of_Protestant_Reformers" title="List of Protestant Reformers">figures in the Protestant Reformation</a>, as well as in the 17th century by secular intellectuals in the Enlightenment. Concurrently, Spanish and Portuguese explorers and missionaries spread the church's influence through Africa, Asia, and the <a href="/wiki/New_World" title="New World">New World</a>.
</p><p>In 1870, the <a href="/wiki/First_Vatican_Council" title="First Vatican Council">First Vatican Council</a> declared the dogma of <a href="/wiki/Papal_infallibility" title="Papal infallibility">papal infallibility</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a> annexed the city of Rome, the last portion of the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a> to be incorporated into the new nation. In the 20th century, anti-clerical governments around the world, including Mexico and Spain, persecuted or executed thousands of clerics and laypersons. In the Second World War, the church condemned Nazism, and protected hundreds of thousands of Jews from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">Holocaust</a>; its efforts, however, have been criticised as inadequate. After the war, freedom of religion was severely restricted in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist" title="Communist">Communist</a> countries newly aligned with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, several of which had large Catholic populations.
</p><p>In the 1960s, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> led to reforms of the church's liturgy and practices, described as "opening the windows" by defenders, but criticised by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditionalist_Catholic" title="Traditionalist Catholic">traditionalist Catholics</a>. In the face of increased criticism from both within and without, the church has upheld or reaffirmed at various times controversial doctrinal positions regarding sexuality and gender, including limiting clergy to males, and moral exhortations against <a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">abortion</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Contraception" title="Contraception">contraception</a>, <a href="/wiki/Human_sexual_activity#Sex_outside_of_marriage" title="Human sexual activity">sexual activity</a> outside of marriage, remarriage following <a href="/wiki/Divorce" title="Divorce">divorce</a> without <a href="/wiki/Annulment" title="Annulment">annulment</a>, and against <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage" title="Same-sex marriage">same-sex marriage</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Apostolic_era_and_papacy">Apostolic era and papacy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_Age" title="Apostolic Age">Apostolic Age</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG/220px-DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG/330px-DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG/440px-DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DambachVille_StEtienne_14.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jesus' commission to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>, in particular the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gospels" title="Gospels">Gospels</a>, records Jesus' activities and teaching, his appointment of the Twelve Apostles and his <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a> of the apostles, instructing them to continue his work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter200430_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter200430-42">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kreeft98O_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft98O-43">[39]</a></sup> The book <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acts_of_Apostles" title="Acts of Apostles">Acts of Apostles</a>, tells of the founding of the Christian church and the spread of its message to the Roman empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[40]</a></sup>  The Catholic Church teaches that its public ministry began on <a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>, occurring fifty days following the date Christ is believed to have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Christ" title="Resurrection of Christ">resurrected</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barry48_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barry48-45">[41]</a></sup> At Pentecost, the apostles are believed to have received the Holy Spirit, preparing them for their mission in leading the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[43]</a></sup> The Catholic Church teaches that the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/College_of_bishops" title="College of bishops">college of bishops</a>, led by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" title="Bishop of Rome">bishop of Rome</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">successors</a> to the Apostles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the account of the <a href="/wiki/Confession_of_Peter" title="Confession of Peter">Confession of Peter</a> found in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a>, Christ designates Peter as the "rock" upon which Christ's church will be built.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup> The Catholic Church considers the bishop of Rome, the pope, to be the successor to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[47]</a></sup> Some scholars state Peter was the first bishop of Rome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JoyceCE1913_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-JoyceCE1913-52">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[note 5]</a></sup> Others say that the institution of the papacy is not dependent on the idea that Peter was bishop of Rome or even on his ever having been in Rome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[49]</a></sup> Many scholars hold that a church structure of plural presbyters/bishops persisted in Rome until the mid-2nd century, when the structure of a single bishop and plural presbyters was adopted,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REB_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-REB-55">[50]</a></sup> and that later writers retrospectively applied the term "bishop of Rome" to the most prominent members of the clergy in the earlier period and also to Peter himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REB_55-1"><a href="#cite_note-REB-55">[50]</a></sup> On this basis, <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Cullmann" title="Oscar Cullmann">Oscar Cullmann</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Henry_Chadwick_(theologian)" title="Henry Chadwick (theologian)">Henry Chadwick</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[52]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Bart_D._Ehrman" title="Bart D. Ehrman">Bart D. Ehrman</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ehrman_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-ehrman-58">[53]</a></sup> question whether there was a formal link between Peter and the modern papacy. <a href="/wiki/Raymond_E._Brown" title="Raymond E. Brown">Raymond E. Brown</a> also says that it is anachronistic to speak of Peter in terms of local bishop of Rome, but that Christians of that period would have looked on Peter as having "roles that would contribute in an essential way to the development of the role of the papacy in the subsequent church". These roles, Brown says, "contributed enormously to seeing the bishop of Rome, the bishop of the city where Peter died and where Paul witnessed the truth of Christ, as the successor of Peter in care for the church universal".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-REB_55-2"><a href="#cite_note-REB-55">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity_and_Roman_Empire">Antiquity and Roman Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_centers_of_Christianity" title="Early centers of Christianity">Early centers of Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy" title="Pentarchy">Pentarchy</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_heresies" title="List of Christian heresies">List of Christian heresies</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-top-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg"><img alt="Emblem of the Papacy SE.svg" data-file-height="1105" data-file-width="815" decoding="async" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/25px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/38px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/50px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" width="25"/></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle-with-top-image">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Ecumenical_councils" title="Category:Ecumenical councils">a series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_ecumenical_councils" title="Catholic ecumenical councils">Ecumenical councils</a><br/>of the <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Catholic Church</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Council_Trent.jpg" title="A Renaissance print depicting the Council of Trent"><img alt="A Renaissance print depicting the Council of Trent" data-file-height="224" data-file-width="323" decoding="async" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Council_Trent.jpg/170px-Council_Trent.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Council_Trent.jpg/255px-Council_Trent.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/28/Council_Trent.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a><div class="sidebar-caption">Renaissance depiction of the Council of Trent</div></td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">

</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">

<li><a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Vatican II (1962–65)</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_ecumenical_councils" title="Template:Catholic ecumenical councils"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_ecumenical_councils" title="Template talk:Catholic ecumenical councils"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_ecumenical_councils&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Conditions in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> facilitated the spread of new ideas. The empire's network of roads and waterways facilitated travel, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Pax_Romana" title="Pax Romana">Pax Romana</a></i> made travelling safe. The empire encouraged the spread of a common culture with Greek roots, which allowed ideas to be more easily expressed and understood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter200424_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter200424-59">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>Unlike most religions in the Roman Empire, however, Christianity required its adherents to renounce all other gods, a practice adopted from Judaism (see <a href="/wiki/Idolatry" title="Idolatry">Idolatry</a>). The Christians' refusal to join <a href="/wiki/Paganism" title="Paganism">pagan</a> celebrations meant they were unable to participate in much of public life, which caused non-Christians—including government authorities—to fear that the Christians were angering the gods and thereby threatening the peace and prosperity of the Empire. The <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians_in_the_Roman_Empire" title="Persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire">resulting persecutions</a> were a defining feature of Christian self-understanding until Christianity was legalised in the 4th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-macculloch155and164_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-macculloch155and164-60">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="551" data-file-width="831" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg/220px-Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg/330px-Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg/440px-Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Basilica_di_San_Pietro_1450.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>19th-century drawing by <a href="/wiki/Henry_William_Brewer" title="Henry William Brewer">Henry William Brewer</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica" title="Old Saint Peter's Basilica">Old Saint Peter's Basilica</a>, originally built in 318 by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_Constantine" title="Emperor Constantine">Emperor Constantine</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 313, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constantine_I_and_Christianity" title="Constantine I and Christianity">Emperor Constantine I</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Milan" title="Edict of Milan">Edict of Milan</a> legalised Christianity, and in 330 Constantine moved the imperial capital to <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul,_Turkey" title="Istanbul, Turkey">Istanbul, Turkey</a>. In 380 the <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Thessalonica" title="Edict of Thessalonica">Edict of Thessalonica</a> made <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nicene_Christianity" title="Nicene Christianity">Nicene Christianity</a> the <a href="/wiki/State_church_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="State church of the Roman Empire">state church of the Roman Empire</a>, a position that within the diminishing territory of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> would persist until the empire itself ended in the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fall of Constantinople</a> in 1453, while elsewhere the church was independent of the empire, as became particularly clear with the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a>. During the period of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seven_Ecumenical_Councils" title="Seven Ecumenical Councils">Seven Ecumenical Councils</a>, five primary sees emerged, an arrangement formalised in the mid-6th century by Emperor <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian I</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Pentarchy" title="Pentarchy">pentarchy</a> of Rome, <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople">Constantinople</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_of_Antioch" title="Patriarch of Antioch">Antioch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_in_Christianity" title="Jerusalem in Christianity">Jerusalem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_of_Alexandria" title="Patriarch of Alexandria">Alexandria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Valliere2012_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-Valliere2012-61">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bartholomew2008_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bartholomew2008-62">[57]</a></sup> In 451 the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a>, in a canon of disputed validity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Michalopulos_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-Michalopulos-63">[58]</a></sup> elevated the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/See_of_Constantinople" title="See of Constantinople">see of Constantinople</a> to a position "second in eminence and power to the bishop of Rome".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Noble214_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Noble214-64">[59]</a></sup> From c. 350 to c. 500, the bishops, or popes, of Rome, steadily increased in authority through their consistent intervening in support of <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_see#Catholic_Church" title="Episcopal see">orthodox leaders</a> in theological disputes, which encouraged appeals to them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-65">[60]</a></sup> Emperor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Justinian" title="Justinian">Justinian</a>, who in the areas under his control definitively established a form of <a href="/wiki/Caesaropapism" title="Caesaropapism">caesaropapism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[61]</a></sup> in which "he had the right and duty of regulating by his laws the minutest details of worship and discipline, and also of dictating the theological opinions to be held in the Church",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[62]</a></sup> re-established imperial power over Rome and other parts of the West, initiating the period termed the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Papacy" title="Byzantine Papacy">Byzantine Papacy</a> (537–752), during which the bishops of Rome, or popes, required approval from the emperor in Constantinople or from his representative in Ravenna for consecration, and most were selected by the emperor from his Greek-speaking subjects,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[63]</a></sup> resulting in a "melting pot" of Western and Eastern Christian traditions in art as well as liturgy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the Germanic tribes who in the following centuries invaded the Roman Empire had adopted Christianity in its <a href="/wiki/Arianism" title="Arianism">Arian</a> form, which the Catholic Church declared <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_heresy" title="Christian heresy">heretical</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[65]</a></sup> The resulting religious discord between Germanic rulers and Catholic subjects<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[66]</a></sup> was avoided when, in 497, <a href="/wiki/Clovis_I" title="Clovis I">Clovis I</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Franks" title="Franks">Frankish</a> ruler, converted to orthodox Catholicism, allying himself with the papacy and the monasteries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[67]</a></sup> The Visigoths in Spain followed his lead in 589,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[68]</a></sup> and the Lombards in Italy in the course of the 7th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christianity</a>, particularly through its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_monasticism" title="Western monasticism">monasteries</a>, was a major factor in preserving <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">classical civilisation</a>, with its art (see <a href="/wiki/Illuminated_manuscript" title="Illuminated manuscript">Illuminated manuscript</a>) and literacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cahill_Thomas_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cahill_Thomas-75">[70]</a></sup> Through his <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_Saint_Benedict" title="Rule of Saint Benedict">Rule</a>, <a href="/wiki/Benedict_of_Nursia" title="Benedict of Nursia">Benedict of Nursia</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 480</span>–543), one of the founders of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_monasticism" title="Western monasticism">Western monasticism</a>, exerted an enormous influence on European culture through the appropriation of the monastic spiritual heritage of the early Catholic Church and, with the spread of the Benedictine tradition, through the preservation and transmission of ancient culture. During this period, monastic Ireland became a centre of learning and early Irish missionaries such as <a href="/wiki/Columbanus" title="Columbanus">Columbanus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Columba" title="Columba">Columba</a> spread Christianity and established monasteries across continental Europe.<sup class="reference plainlinks nourlexpansion" id="ref_{{{1}}}"><a class="external autonumber" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_Church#endnote_">[1]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages_and_Renaissance">Middle Ages and Renaissance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Christianity_during_the_Middle_Ages" title="History of Christianity during the Middle Ages">History of Christianity during the Middle Ages</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_16th_century#Renaissance_Church" title="Christianity in the 16th century">Christianity in the 16th century § Renaissance Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1793" data-file-width="2121" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG/260px-Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG/390px-Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG/520px-Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chartres_Cath%2BGare.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chartres_Cathedral" title="Chartres Cathedral">Chartres Cathedral</a>, completed 1220</div></div></div>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="background-color:gold">Schools</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Augustinianism" title="Augustinianism">Augustinianism</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cartesianism" title="Cartesianism">Cartesianism</a></li>
