<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Persecutions_of_the_Catholic_Church_sidebar" title="Template:Persecutions of the Catholic Church sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Persecutions_of_the_Catholic_Church_sidebar" title="Template talk:Persecutions of the Catholic Church sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Persecutions_of_the_Catholic_Church_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_(Brazil).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2441" data-file-width="3253" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg/220px-S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg/330px-S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg/440px-S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_%28Brazil%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es_(Brazil).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ruins of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuit_Reduction" title="Jesuit Reduction">Jesuit Reduction</a> at <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Miguel_das_Miss%C3%B5es" title="São Miguel das Missões">São Miguel das Missões</a> in Brazil</div></div></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a></div>
<p>From the 17th century onward, the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> questioned the power and influence of the Catholic Church over Western society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pollard8_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pollard8-108">[103]</a></sup> In the 18th century, writers such as <a href="/wiki/Voltaire" title="Voltaire">Voltaire</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A9distes" title="Encyclopédistes">Encyclopédistes</a></i> wrote biting critiques of both religion and the Catholic Church. One target of their criticism was the 1685 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Revocation_of_the_Edict_of_Nantes" title="Revocation of the Edict of Nantes">revocation of the Edict of Nantes</a> by King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France" title="Louis XIV of France">Louis XIV of France</a>, which ended a century-long policy of religious toleration of Protestant Huguenots. As the papacy resisted pushes for <a href="/wiki/Gallicanism" title="Gallicanism">Gallicanism</a>, the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> of 1789 shifted power to the state, caused the destruction of churches, the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Cult_of_Reason" title="Cult of Reason">Cult of Reason</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004283–285_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004283–285-109">[104]</a></sup> and the martyrdom of <a href="/wiki/Martyrs_of_Compi%C3%A8gne" title="Martyrs of Compiègne">nuns</a> during the <i><a href="/wiki/Reign_of_Terror" title="Reign of Terror">Reign of Terror</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[105]</a></sup> In 1798, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France" title="Napoleon I of France">Napoleon Bonaparte</a>'s General <a href="/wiki/Louis-Alexandre_Berthier" title="Louis-Alexandre Berthier">Louis-Alexandre Berthier</a> invaded the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">Italian Peninsula</a>, imprisoning <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_VI" title="Pope Pius VI">Pope Pius VI</a>, who died in captivity. Napoleon later re-established the Catholic Church in France through the <a href="/wiki/Concordat_of_1801" title="Concordat of 1801">Concordat of 1801</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Collins176_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-Collins176-111">[106]</a></sup> The end of the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> brought Catholic revival and the return of the <a href="/wiki/Papal_States" title="Papal States">Papal States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1854, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX" title="Pope Pius IX">Pope Pius IX</a>, with the support of the overwhelming majority of Catholic bishops, whom he had consulted from 1851 to 1853, proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Immaculate_Conception" title="Immaculate Conception">Immaculate Conception</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Dogma_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Dogma in the Catholic Church">dogma in the Catholic Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[108]</a></sup> In 1870, the <a href="/wiki/First_Vatican_Council" title="First Vatican Council">First Vatican Council</a> affirmed the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Papal_infallibility" title="Papal infallibility">papal infallibility</a> when exercised in specifically defined pronouncements,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Leith_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-Leith-114">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Duffy232_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-Duffy232-115">[110]</a></sup> striking a blow to the rival position of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conciliar_Church" title="Conciliar Church">conciliarism</a>. Controversy over this and other issues resulted in a breakaway movement called the <a href="/wiki/Old_Catholic_Church#Impact_of_the_First_Vatican_Council:_second_stage" title="Old Catholic Church">Old Catholic Church</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fahlbusch_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fahlbusch-116">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">Italian unification</a> of the 1860s incorporated the Papal States, including Rome itself from 1870, into the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a>, thus ending the papacy's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temporal_power_(papal)" title="Temporal power (papal)">temporal power</a>. In response, Pope Pius IX excommunicated <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_II" title="Victor Emmanuel II">King Victor Emmanuel II</a>, refused payment for the land, and rejected the Italian <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Guarantees" title="Law of Guarantees">Law of Guarantees</a>, which granted him special privileges. To avoid placing himself in visible subjection to the Italian authorities, he remained a "<a href="/wiki/Prisoner_in_the_Vatican" title="Prisoner in the Vatican">prisoner in the Vatican</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[112]</a></sup> This stand-off, which was spoken of as the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Question" title="Roman Question">Roman Question</a></i>, was resolved by the 1929 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lateran_Treaties" title="Lateran Treaties">Lateran Treaties</a>, whereby the Holy See acknowledged Italian sovereignty over the former Papal States in return for payment and Italy's recognition of papal sovereignty over Vatican City as a new sovereign and independent state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholic missionaries generally supported, and sought to facilitate, the European imperial powers' <a href="/wiki/Scramble_for_Africa" title="Scramble for Africa">conquest of Africa</a> during the late nineteenth century. According to the historian of religion <a href="/wiki/Adrian_Hastings" title="Adrian Hastings">Adrian Hastings</a>, Catholic missionaries were generally unwilling to defend African rights or encourage Africans to see themselves as equals to Europeans, in contrast to Protestant missionaries, who were more willing to oppose colonial injustices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century">20th century</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_the_20th_century" title="Catholic Church in the 20th century">Catholic Church in the 20th century</a></div>
<p>During the 20th century, the Church's global reach continued to grow, despite the rise of anti-Catholic authoritarian regimes and the collapse of European Empires, accompanied by a general decline in religious observance in the West. Under Popes <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benedict_XV" title="Benedict XV">Benedict XV</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pius_XII" title="Pius XII">Pius XII</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> sought to maintain public neutrality through the World Wars, acting as peace broker and delivering aid to the victims of the conflicts. In the 1960s, <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII" title="Pope John XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a> convened the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a>, which ushered in radical change to Church ritual and practice, and in the later 20th century, the long reign of <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> contributed to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fall_of_Communism" title="Fall of Communism">Fall of Communism</a> in Europe, and a new public and international role for the papacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[115]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>World War One</dt></dl>
<p>Pope <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pius_X" title="Pius X">Pius X</a> (1903–1914) renewed the independence of papal office by abolishing the veto of Catholic powers in papal elections, and his successors <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benedict_XV" title="Benedict XV">Benedict XV</a> (1914–1922) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pius_XI" title="Pius XI">Pius XI</a> (1922–1939) concluded the modern independence of the Vatican State within Italy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[116]</a></sup> Benedict XV was elected at the outbreak of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">First World War</a>. He attempted to mediate between the powers and established a Vatican relief office, to assist victims of the war and reunite families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[117]</a></sup> He offered numerous appeals for peace. His "Dès le début" initiative of 1 August 1917 was rejected by the warring parties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Interwar years</dt></dl>
<p>A number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anti-clerical" title="Anti-clerical">anti-clerical</a> governments emerged in the 20th century. The 1926 <a href="/wiki/Calles_Law" title="Calles Law">Calles Law</a> separating church and state in Mexico led to the <a href="/wiki/Cristero_War" title="Cristero War">Cristero War</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chadwick264_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chadwick264-124">[119]</a></sup> in which more than 3,000 priests were exiled or assassinated,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scheina_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scheina-125">[120]</a></sup> churches desecrated, services mocked, nuns raped, and captured priests shot.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chadwick264_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chadwick264-124">[119]</a></sup> Following the 1917 <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a>, persecution of the church and Catholics in the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> continued into the 1930s, with the execution and exiling of clerics, monks and laymen, the confiscation of religious implements, and closure of churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Riasanovsky_634_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-Riasanovsky_634-127">[122]</a></sup> In the 1936–39 <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War" title="Spanish Civil War">Spanish Civil War</a>, the Catholic hierarchy allied with <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Franco" title="Francisco Franco">Franco's</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_State" title="Spanish State">Nationalists</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Popular_Front_(Spain)" title="Popular Front (Spain)">Popular Front</a> government,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[123]</a></sup> citing as justification <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror_(Spain)" title="Red Terror (Spain)">Republican violence</a> against the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[125]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI" title="Pope Pius XI">Pope Pius XI</a> referred to these three countries as a "terrible triangle".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-divinired_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-divinired-132">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="312" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="86" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg/220px-V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg/330px-V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg/440px-V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:V-2_Rocket_On_Meillerwagen.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>While, since the 1960s, Pope Pius XII has been accused of not having done enough to shelter Jews from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust">Holocaust</a>, his defenders claim he secretly encouraged individual Catholic resistance groups,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[130]</a></sup> such as that led by priest <a href="/wiki/Heinrich_Maier" title="Heinrich Maier">Heinrich Maier</a>. Maier helped the allies fight against the V-2, which was produced by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_concentration_camps" title="Nazi concentration camps">concentration camp</a> prisoners.</div></div></div>
<p>The interwar <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XI" title="Pope Pius XI">Pope Pius XI</a> modernised the papacy by appearing in St Peter's Square, founding <a href="/wiki/Vatican_Radio" title="Vatican Radio">Vatican Radio</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Pontifical_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Pontifical Academy of Sciences">Papal Academy of Sciences</a>, appointing 40 indigenous bishops and concluding fifteen concordats, including the <a href="/wiki/Lateran_Treaty" title="Lateran Treaty">Lateran Treaty</a> with Italy which founded the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vatican_City_State" title="Vatican City State">Vatican City State</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[131]</a></sup> After violations of the 1933 <a href="/wiki/Reichskonkordat" title="Reichskonkordat">Reichskonkordat</a> between the church and <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, Pius XI issued the 1937 encyclical <i><a href="/wiki/Mit_brennender_Sorge" title="Mit brennender Sorge">Mit brennender Sorge</a></i>, which publicly condemned the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_persecution_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_Germany" title="Nazi persecution of the Catholic Church in Germany">Nazis' persecution of the church</a> and their ideology of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modern_Paganism" title="Modern Paganism">neopaganism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Supremacism" title="Supremacism">racial superiority</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rhodes182_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rhodes182-137">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rhodes197_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rhodes197-138">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rhodes204_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rhodes204-139">[134]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>World War Two</dt></dl>
<p>His successor <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a> led the Church through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">Second World War</a> and early <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. Like his predecessors, Pius XII sought to publicly maintain Vatican neutrality in the War, and established aid networks to help victims, but he secretly <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII_and_the_German_Resistance" title="Pope Pius XII and the German Resistance">assisted the anti-Hitler resistance</a> and shared intelligence with the Allies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[135]</a></sup> His first encyclical <i><a href="/wiki/Summi_Pontificatus" title="Summi Pontificatus">Summi Pontificatus</a></i> (1939) expressed dismay at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1939_Invasion_of_Poland" title="1939 Invasion of Poland">1939 Invasion of Poland</a> and reiterated Catholic teaching against <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cook983_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cook983-141">[136]</a></sup> He expressed concern against race killings <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII%27s_1942_Christmas_address" title="Pope Pius XII's 1942 Christmas address">on Vatican Radio</a>, and intervened diplomatically to attempt to block Nazi deportations of Jews in various countries from 1942 to 1944. But the Pope's insistence on public neutrality and diplomatic language has become a source of much criticism and debate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[137]</a></sup> Nevertheless, in every country under German occupation, priests played a major part in rescuing Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[138]</a></sup> Israeli historian <a href="/wiki/Pinchas_Lapide" title="Pinchas Lapide">Pinchas Lapide</a> estimated that <a href="/wiki/Rescue_of_Jews_by_Catholics_during_the_Holocaust" title="Rescue of Jews by Catholics during the Holocaust">Catholic rescue of Jews</a> amounted to somewhere between 700,000 and 860,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Nazi_persecution_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_Germany" title="Nazi persecution of the Catholic Church in Germany">Nazi persecution of the Catholic Church</a> was at its most intense <a href="/wiki/Nazi_persecution_of_the_Catholic_Church_in_Poland" title="Nazi persecution of the Catholic Church in Poland">in Poland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_resistance_to_Nazi_Germany" title="Catholic resistance to Nazi Germany">Catholic resistance to Nazism</a> took various forms. Some 2,579 Catholic clergy were sent to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Priest_Barracks_of_Dachau" title="Priest Barracks of Dachau">Priest Barracks</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dachau_Concentration_Camp" title="Dachau Concentration Camp">Dachau Concentration Camp</a>, including 400 Germans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[141]</a></sup> Thousands of priests, nuns and brothers were imprisoned, taken to a concentration camp, tortured and murdered, including Saints <a href="/wiki/Maximilian_Kolbe" title="Maximilian Kolbe">Maximilian Kolbe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Edith_Stein" title="Edith Stein">Edith Stein</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[143]</a></sup> Catholics fought on both sides in the conflict. Catholic clergy played a leading role in the government of the fascist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slovak_State" title="Slovak State">Slovak State</a>, which collaborated with the Nazis, copied their anti-Semitic policies, and helped them carry out the Holocaust in Slovakia. <a href="/wiki/Jozef_Tiso" title="Jozef Tiso">Jozef Tiso</a>, the President of the Slovak State and a Catholic priest, supported his government's deportation of Slovakian Jews to extermination camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[144]</a></sup> The Vatican protested against these Jewish deportations in Slovakia and in other Nazi puppet regimes including <a href="/wiki/Vichy_France" title="Vichy France">Vichy France</a>, Croatia, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, Italy and Hungary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Catholic resistance group around the priest <a href="/wiki/Heinrich_Maier" title="Heinrich Maier">Heinrich Maier</a> passed on plans and production facilities for <a href="/wiki/V-1_flying_bomb" title="V-1 flying bomb">V-1 flying bombs</a>, <a href="/wiki/V-2_rocket" title="V-2 rocket">V-2 rockets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tiger_tank" title="Tiger tank">Tiger tanks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Messerschmitt_Me_163_Komet" title="Messerschmitt Me 163 Komet">Messerschmitt Me 163 Komet</a> and other aircraft to the Allies, with which they could target German production facilities. Much of the information was important to <a href="/wiki/Operation_Hydra_(1943)" title="Operation Hydra (1943)">Operation Hydra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Crossbow" title="Operation Crossbow">Operation Crossbow</a>, both critical operations to <a href="/wiki/Operation_Overlord" title="Operation Overlord">Operation Overlord</a>. He and his group informed the American <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Strategic_Services" title="Office of Strategic Services">Office of Strategic Services</a> early on about the mass murder of Jews in Auschwitz. Maier supported the war against the Nazis on the principle "every bomb that falls on armaments factories shortens the war and spares the civilian population."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="455" data-file-width="633" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg/220px-Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg/330px-Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg/440px-Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Members_of_the_Royal_22e_Regiment_in_audience_with_Pope_Pius_XII.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Members of the Canadian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_22e_Regiment" title="Royal 22e Regiment">Royal 22<sup>e</sup> Regiment</a> in audience with <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a>, following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liberation_of_Rome" title="Liberation of Rome">Liberation of Rome</a> in 1944 during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a></div></div></div>
<p>Around 1943, <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> planned the kidnapping of the Pope and his internment in Germany. He gave SS General Wolff a corresponding order to prepare for the action.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[149]</a></sup> While <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a> has been credited with helping to <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII_and_the_Holocaust" title="Pope Pius XII and the Holocaust">save hundreds of thousands of Jews</a> during the <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">Holocaust</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004192_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004192-155">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Deák_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Deák-156">[151]</a></sup> the church has also been accused of having encouraged centuries of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianity_and_antisemitism" title="Christianity and antisemitism">antisemitism</a> by its teachings<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[152]</a></sup> and not doing enough to stop Nazi atrocities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[153]</a></sup> Many Nazi criminals escaped overseas after the Second World War, also because they had powerful supporters from the Vatican.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[156]</a></sup> The judgment of Pius XII. is made more difficult by the sources, because the church archives for his tenure as nuncio, cardinal secretary of state and pope are in part closed or not yet processed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Yugoslavia" title="Invasion of Yugoslavia">dismembered Yugoslavia</a>, the Church favored the Nazi-installed Croatian Catholic fascist <a href="/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e" title="Ustaše">Ustaše</a> regime due to its anti-communist ideology and for the potential to reinstate Catholic influence in the region following the dissolution of <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phayer2000p32_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-Phayer2000p32-163">[158]</a></sup> It did not however formally recognise the <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a> (NDH).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Phayer2000p32_163-1"><a href="#cite_note-Phayer2000p32-163">[158]</a></sup> Despite being informed of the regime's <a href="/wiki/Genocide_of_Serbs_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Genocide of Serbs in the Independent State of Croatia">genocide against Orthodox Serbs</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="The Holocaust in the Independent State of Croatia">Jews</a> and other non-Croats, the Church did not publicly speak out against it, preferring to exert pressure through diplomacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[159]</a></sup> In assessing the Vatican's position, historian <a href="/wiki/Jozo_Tomasevich" title="Jozo Tomasevich">Jozo Tomasevich</a> writes that "it seems the Catholic Church fully supported the [Ustaše] regime and its policies."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Early Cold War</dt></dl>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Post-war" title="Post-war">post-war</a> period, Communist governments in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> severely restricted religious freedoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-communist_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-communist-166">[161]</a></sup> Although some priests and religious people collaborated with Communist regimes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[162]</a></sup> many others were imprisoned, deported, or executed. The church was an important player in the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">fall of Communism</a> in Europe, particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People's Republic">Polish People's Republic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1949, the Communist victory in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> led to the expulsion of all foreign missionaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004356–358_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter2004356–358-169">[164]</a></sup> The new government also created the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patriotic_Church" title="Patriotic Church">Patriotic Church</a> and appointed its bishops. These appointments were initially rejected by Rome before many of them were accepted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[165]</a></sup> In the 1960s during the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, the Chinese Communists closed all religious establishments. When Chinese churches eventually reopened, they remained under the control of the Patriotic Church. Many Catholic priests continued to be sent to prison for refusing to renounce allegiance to Rome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[166]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_Vatican_Council">Second Vatican Council</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1328" data-file-width="1328" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg/220px-Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg/330px-Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg/440px-Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Second_Vatican_Council_by_Lothar_Wolleh_003.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bishops listen during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_the_Catholic_Church_since_1962" title="History of the Catholic Church since 1962">History of the Catholic Church since 1962</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spirit_of_Vatican_II" title="Spirit of Vatican II">Spirit of Vatican II</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> (1962–1965) introduced the most significant changes to Catholic practices since the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a>, four centuries before.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[167]</a></sup> Initiated by <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII" title="Pope John XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a>, this ecumenical council modernised the practices of the Catholic Church, allowing the Mass to be said in the <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">vernacular</a> (local language) and encouraging "fully conscious, and active participation in liturgical celebrations".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[168]</a></sup> It intended to engage the Church more closely with the present world (<i><a href="/wiki/Aggiornamento" title="Aggiornamento">aggiornamento</a></i>), which was described by its advocates as an "opening of the windows".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Duffy272_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-Duffy272-174">[169]</a></sup> In addition to changes in the liturgy, it led to changes to the church's approach to <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_ecumenism" title="Catholic Church and ecumenism">ecumenism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[170]</a></sup> and a call to improved relations with non-Christian religions, especially <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, in its document <i><a href="/wiki/Nostra_aetate" title="Nostra aetate">Nostra aetate</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOSTRA_AETATE_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-NOSTRA_AETATE-176">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>The council, however, generated significant controversy in implementing its reforms: proponents of the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spirit_of_Vatican_II" title="Spirit of Vatican II">Spirit of Vatican II</a>" such as Swiss theologian <a href="/wiki/Hans_K%C3%BCng" title="Hans Küng">Hans Küng</a> said that Vatican II had "not gone far enough" to change church policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[172]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditionalist_Catholics" title="Traditionalist Catholics">Traditionalist Catholics</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Archbishop" title="Archbishop">Archbishop</a> <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Lefebvre" title="Marcel Lefebvre">Marcel Lefebvre</a>, however, strongly criticised the council, arguing that its liturgical reforms led "to the destruction of the Holy Sacrifice of the Mass and the sacraments", among other issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several teachings of the Catholic Church came under increased scrutiny both concurrent with and following the council; among those teachings was the church's teaching regarding the immorality of <a href="/wiki/Birth_control" title="Birth control">contraception</a>. The recent introduction of <a href="/wiki/Hormonal_contraception" title="Hormonal contraception">hormonal contraception</a> (including "the pill"), which were believed by some to be morally different from previous methods, prompted John XXIII to form a committee to advise him of the moral and theological issues with the new method.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[175]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Pope Paul VI</a> later expanded the committee's scope to freely examine all methods, and the committee's unreleased final report was rumoured to suggest permitting at least some methods of contraception. Paul did not agree with the arguments presented, and eventually issued <i><a href="/wiki/Humanae_vitae" title="Humanae vitae">Humanae vitae</a></i>, saying that it upheld the constant teaching of the church against contraception. It expressly included hormonal methods as prohibited.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[note 6]</a></sup> This document generated a largely negative response from many Catholics.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (September 2016)">from whom?</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HV_then_now_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-HV_then_now-182">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="John_Paul_II">John Paul II</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2617" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg/220px-President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg/330px-President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg/440px-President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Ronald_Reagan_and_Nancy_Reagan_meet_with_Pope_John_Paul_II_at_the_Vatican_Library.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> is credited as a major influence to the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fall_of_communism" title="Fall of communism">fall of communism</a>. Here with U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> and his wife, <a href="/wiki/Nancy_Reagan" title="Nancy Reagan">Nancy</a>, in 1982.</div></div></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a></div>
<p>In 1978, <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a>, formerly <a href="/wiki/Archbishop_of_Krak%C3%B3w" title="Archbishop of Kraków">Archbishop of Kraków</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People's Republic">Polish People's Republic</a>, became the first non-Italian pope in 455 years. His 26 1/2-year <a href="/wiki/Pontificate" title="Pontificate">pontificate</a> was one of the longest in history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[177]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, the president of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, credited the Polish pope with hastening the fall of Communism in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[178]</a></sup>
</p><p>John Paul II sought to evangelise an increasingly <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular world</a>. He instituted <a href="/wiki/World_Youth_Day" title="World Youth Day">World Youth Day</a> as a "worldwide encounter with the pope" for young people; it is now held every two to three years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[179]</a></sup> He travelled more than any other pope, visiting 129 countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[180]</a></sup> and used television and radio as means of spreading the church's teachings. He also emphasised the <a href="/wiki/Dignity_of_labour" title="Dignity of labour">dignity of work</a> and natural rights of labourers to have <a href="/wiki/Living_wage" title="Living wage">fair wages</a> and safe conditions in <i><a href="/wiki/Laborem_exercens" title="Laborem exercens">Laborem exercens</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[181]</a></sup> He emphasised several church teachings, including moral exhortations against <a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">abortion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Euthanasia" title="Euthanasia">euthanasia</a>, and against widespread use of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_penalty" title="Death penalty">death penalty</a>, in <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evangelium_Vitae" title="Evangelium Vitae">Evangelium Vitae</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the late 20th century, the Catholic Church has been <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Criticism of the Catholic Church">criticised</a> for its doctrines on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_teachings_on_sexual_morality" title="Catholic teachings on sexual morality">sexuality</a>, its inability to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_doctrine_on_the_ordination_of_women" title="Catholic Church doctrine on the ordination of women">ordain women</a>, and its handling of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_sexual_abuse_cases" title="Catholic Church sexual abuse cases">sexual abuse cases</a>.
</p><p>In 1992, the Vatican acknowledged its error in persecuting <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galileo" title="Galileo">Galileo</a> 359 years earlier for proving the Earth revolved around the Sun.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[184]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="21st_century">21st century</span></h3>
<p>In 2005, following the death of John Paul II, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a>, head of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Doctrine_of_the_Faith" title="Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith">Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith</a> under John Paul II, was elected. He was known for upholding traditional <a href="/wiki/Christian_values" title="Christian values">Christian values</a> against <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secularisation" title="Secularisation">secularisation</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[185]</a></sup> and for increasing use of the <a href="/wiki/Tridentine_Mass" title="Tridentine Mass">Tridentine Mass</a> as found in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Missal" title="Roman Missal">Roman Missal</a> of 1962, which he titled the "Extraordinary Form".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[186]</a></sup> In 2012, the 50th anniversary of Vatican II, an assembly of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Synod_of_Bishops_(Catholic)" title="Synod of Bishops (Catholic)">Synod of Bishops</a> discussed re-evangelising <a href="/wiki/Lapsed_Catholic" title="Lapsed Catholic">lapsed Catholics</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Summary_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-Summary-193">[187]</a></sup> Citing the frailties of advanced age, Benedict <a href="/wiki/Resignation_of_Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Resignation of Pope Benedict XVI">resigned</a> in 2013, becoming the first pope to do so in nearly 600 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[188]</a></sup> His resignation has caused controversy among a minority of Catholics<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (June 2021)">who?</span></a></i>]</sup> who say Benedict did not fully resign the papacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pope_Francis">Pope Francis</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a></div>
<p>Pope Francis, the current pope of the Catholic Church, succeeded Pope Benedict XVI in 2013 as the first pope from the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a>, the first from the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>, and the first Pope from outside Europe since the Syrian <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_III" title="Pope Gregory III">Gregory III</a>, who reigned in the 8th century. Pope Francis has been noted for his <a href="/wiki/Humility" title="Humility">humility</a>, emphasis on God's mercy, concern for the <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poor</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Environment_(biophysical)" title="Environment (biophysical)">environment</a>, as well as his commitment to <a href="/wiki/Interfaith_dialogue" title="Interfaith dialogue">interfaith dialogue</a>. Media commentators Rachel Donadio of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i> and Brandon Ambrosino of <i><a href="/wiki/Vox_Media" title="Vox Media">Vox</a></i> credit Pope Francis with having a less formal approach to the papacy than his predecessors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pope Francis is recognised<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (June 2021)">by whom?</span></a></i>]</sup> for his efforts "to further close the nearly 1,000-year estrangement with the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox Churches</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-orthodox_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-orthodox-198">[192]</a></sup> His installation was attended by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patriarch_Bartholomew_I_of_Constantinople" title="Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople">Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-patriarch_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-patriarch-199">[193]</a></sup> the first time since the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">Great Schism</a> of 1054 that the Eastern Orthodox <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople</a> has attended a papal installation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[194]</a></sup> On 12 February 2016, Pope Francis and <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_Kirill_of_Moscow" title="Patriarch Kirill of Moscow">Patriarch Kirill of Moscow</a>, head of the largest Eastern Orthodox church, met in <a href="/wiki/Havana" title="Havana">Havana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, issuing <a href="/wiki/Joint_Declaration_of_Pope_Francis_and_Patriarch_Kirill" title="Joint Declaration of Pope Francis and Patriarch Kirill">a joint declaration</a> calling for restored Christian unity between the two churches. This was reported as the first such high-level meeting between the two churches since the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">Great Schism</a> of 1054.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, the <a href="/wiki/Third_Extraordinary_General_Assembly_of_the_Synod_of_Bishops" title="Third Extraordinary General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops">Third Extraordinary General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops</a> addressed the church's ministry towards families and marriages and to Catholics in "irregular" relationships, such as those who <a href="/wiki/Divorce" title="Divorce">divorced</a> and remarried outside of the church without a <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_nullity" title="Declaration of nullity">declaration of nullity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[196]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[197]</a></sup> While welcomed by some, it was criticised by some for perceived ambiguity, provoking controversies among individual representatives of differing perspectives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017 during a visit in <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, Pope Francis reestablished mutual recognition of baptism with the <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church" title="Coptic Orthodox Church">Coptic Orthodox Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2021, Pope Francis issued the apostolic letter <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditionis_Custodes" title="Traditionis Custodes">Traditionis Custodes</a></i>, which reversed some of permissions his predecessor had afforded to celebration of the Extraordinary Form of the Roman Rite and emphasized Pope Francis's preference for the Ordinary Form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MPTC_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-MPTC-206">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>On April 1, 2022, during a meeting between a delegation of <a href="/wiki/First_Nations_in_Canada" title="First Nations in Canada">Canadian First Nations</a> representatives and Pope Francis at the Vatican, the pope apologized for the conduct of some members of the Roman Catholic Church in the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Indian_residential_school_system" title="Canadian Indian residential school system">Canadian Indian residential school system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBCPopeApology_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-CBCPopeApology-207">[201]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Organisation">Organisation</span></h2>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Organisation_and_demographics"></span><span class="anchor" id="Organisation_and_demographics"></span>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Hierarchy of the Catholic Church">Hierarchy of the Catholic Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">Catholic Church by country</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1105" data-file-width="815" decoding="async" height="298" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/220px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/330px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/440px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven, and whatever you bind on Earth shall be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on Earth shall be loosed in heaven." Jesus to Peter in the <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_Matthew" title="Gospel of Matthew">Gospel of Matthew</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://www.esv.org/Matthew+16:19" rel="nofollow">16:19</a>  The crossed gold and silver keys of the Holy See symbolise the keys of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Simon_Peter" title="Simon Peter">Simon Peter</a>, representing the power of the papal office to loose and bind. The triple crown <a href="/wiki/Papal_tiara" title="Papal tiara">papal tiara</a> symbolises the triple power of the pope as "father of kings", "governor of the world" and "<a href="/wiki/Vicar_of_Christ" title="Vicar of Christ">Vicar of Christ</a>". The gold cross on a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monde_(crown)" title="Monde (crown)">monde</a> (<a href="/wiki/Globe" title="Globe">globe</a>) surmounting the tiara symbolises the sovereignty of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church follows an <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_polity" title="Episcopal polity">episcopal polity</a>, led by bishops who have received the sacrament of <a href="#Sacraments_at_the_service_of_communion">Holy Orders</a> who are given formal <a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_jurisdiction" title="Ecclesiastical jurisdiction">jurisdictions</a> of governance within the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCC880_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCC880-208">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CEHierarchy_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-CEHierarchy-209">[203]</a></sup> There are three levels of clergy: the episcopate, composed of bishops who hold jurisdiction over a geographic area called a <a href="/wiki/Diocese" title="Diocese">diocese</a> or <a href="/wiki/Eparchy" title="Eparchy">eparchy</a>; the presbyterate, composed of priests ordained by bishops and who work in local dioceses or religious orders; and the diaconate, composed of deacons who assist bishops and priests in a variety of ministerial roles. Ultimately leading the entire Catholic Church is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bishop_of_Rome" title="Bishop of Rome">bishop of Rome</a>, known as the pope (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">papa</i>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a> </small>'father'), whose jurisdiction is called the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> (<span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Sancta Sedes</i></span> in Latin).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-section880_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-section880-210">[204]</a></sup> In parallel to the diocesan structure are a variety of <a href="/wiki/Religious_institute" title="Religious institute">religious institutes</a> that function autonomously, often subject only to the authority of the pope, though sometimes subject to the local bishop. Most religious institutes only have male or female members but some have both. Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_laity" title="Catholic laity">lay members</a> aid many liturgical functions during worship services.
</p>
<h3><span id="Holy_See.2C_papacy.2C_Roman_Curia.2C_and_College_of_Cardinals"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Holy_See,_papacy,_Roman_Curia,_and_College_of_Cardinals">Holy See, papacy, Roman Curia, and College of Cardinals</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Curia" title="Roman Curia">Roman Curia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/College_of_Cardinals" title="College of Cardinals">College of Cardinals</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_popes" title="List of popes">List of popes</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_(14036966125).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2746" data-file-width="2913" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg/220px-Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg/330px-Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg/440px-Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_%2814036966125%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Canonization_2014-The_Canonization_of_Saint_John_XXIII_and_Saint_John_Paul_II_(14036966125).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Francis is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_popes" title="List of popes">266th</a> and current pope of the Catholic Church, a <a href="/wiki/Courtesy_title" title="Courtesy title">title</a> he holds <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ex_officio" title="Ex officio">ex officio</a></i> as bishop of Rome, and sovereign of Vatican City. He was elected in the <a href="/wiki/2013_papal_conclave" title="2013 papal conclave">2013 papal conclave</a>.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile vcard"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-top-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scale_of_justice,_canon_law.svg" title="Scale of justice"><img alt="Scale of justice" data-file-height="182" data-file-width="178" decoding="async" height="102" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg/100px-Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg/150px-Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg/200px-Scale_of_justice%2C_canon_law.svg.png 2x" width="100"/></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle-with-top-image">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Category:Canon law of the Catholic Church">a series</a> on the</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle"><a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law of the<br/>Catholic Church</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">

<p><i>Pars dynamica</i> (trial procedure)
</p>

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title">Law of <a href="/wiki/Consecrated_life" title="Consecrated life">consecrated life</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content" style="text-align:left">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_canon_law" title="Template:Catholic canon law"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_canon_law" title="Template talk:Catholic canon law"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_canon_law&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Hierarchy of the Catholic Church">hierarchy of the Catholic Church</a> is headed<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[note 7]</a></sup> by the pope—currently <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Pope Francis</a>, who was elected on 13 March 2013 by <a href="/wiki/2013_papal_conclave" title="2013 papal conclave">a papal conclave</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-habemus_papem_2013_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-habemus_papem_2013-217">[210]</a></sup> The office of the pope is known as the <i>papacy</i>. The Catholic Church holds that Christ instituted the papacy upon giving the <a href="/wiki/Keys_of_Heaven" title="Keys of Heaven">keys of Heaven</a> to <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter" title="Saint Peter">Saint Peter</a>. His ecclesiastical jurisdiction is called the Holy See, or the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_See" title="Apostolic See">Apostolic See</a> (meaning the see of the apostle Peter).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[212]</a></sup> Directly serving the pope is the Roman Curia, the central governing body that administers the day-to-day business of the Catholic Church.
</p><p>The pope is also <a href="/wiki/Sovereign" title="Sovereign">sovereign</a> of Vatican City,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[213]</a></sup> a small <a href="/wiki/City-state" title="City-state">city-state</a> entirely enclaved within the city of Rome, which is an entity distinct from the Holy See. It is as head of the Holy See, not as head of Vatican City State, that the pope receives ambassadors of states and sends them his own diplomatic representatives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[214]</a></sup> The Holy See also confers <a href="/wiki/Orders,_decorations,_and_medals_of_the_Holy_See" title="Orders, decorations, and medals of the Holy See">orders, decorations and medals</a>, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orders_of_chivalry" title="Orders of chivalry">orders of chivalry</a> originating from the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>.
</p><p>While the famous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Peter%27s_Basilica" title="Saint Peter's Basilica">Saint Peter's Basilica</a> is located in Vatican City, above the traditional site of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Peter%27s_tomb" title="Saint Peter's tomb">Saint Peter's tomb</a>, the papal <a href="/wiki/Cathedral" title="Cathedral">cathedral</a> for the Diocese of Rome is the <a href="/wiki/Archbasilica_of_Saint_John_Lateran" title="Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran">Archbasilica of Saint John Lateran</a>, located within the city of Rome, though enjoying <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extraterritorial" title="Extraterritorial">extraterritorial</a> privileges accredited to the Holy See.
</p><p>The position of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cardinal_(Catholicism)" title="Cardinal (Catholicism)">cardinal</a> is a rank of honour bestowed by popes on certain clerics, such as leaders within the Roman Curia, bishops serving in major cities and distinguished theologians. For advice and assistance in governing, the pope may turn to the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Cardinals" title="College of Cardinals">College of Cardinals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McDonough227_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-McDonough227-222">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the death or resignation of a pope,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[note 8]</a></sup> members of the College of Cardinals who are under age 80 act as an <a href="/wiki/Electoral_college" title="Electoral college">electoral college</a>, meeting in a <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave" title="Papal conclave">papal conclave</a> to elect a successor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-duffy416_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-duffy416-225">[217]</a></sup> Although the conclave may elect any male Catholic as pope, since 1389 only cardinals have been elected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-duffy417and18_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-duffy417and18-226">[218]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Canon_law">Canon law</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law of the Catholic Church</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church#Liturgy" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church § Liturgy</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">jus canonicum</i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[219]</a></sup> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_system" title="Legal system">system</a> of <a href="/wiki/Law" title="Law">laws</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canon_law" title="Canon law">legal principles</a> made and enforced by the <a href="/wiki/Hierarchy_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Hierarchy of the Catholic Church">hierarchical authorities</a> of the Catholic Church to regulate its external organisation and government and to order and direct the activities of Catholics toward the mission of the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[220]</a></sup> The canon law of the Latin Church was the first modern Western <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_system" title="Legal system">legal system</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[221]</a></sup> and is the oldest continuously functioning legal system in the West,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[222]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[223]</a></sup> while the distinctive traditions of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_canon_law" title="Eastern Catholic canon law">Eastern Catholic canon law</a> govern the 23 Eastern Catholic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Particular_church" title="Particular church">particular churches</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris" title="Sui iuris">sui iuris</a></i>.
</p><p>Positive ecclesiastical laws, based directly or indirectly upon immutable divine law or <a href="/wiki/Natural_law" title="Natural law">natural law</a>, derive formal authority in the case of universal laws from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Promulgation_(canon_law)" title="Promulgation (canon law)">promulgation</a> by the supreme legislator—the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supreme_Pontiff" title="Supreme Pontiff">Supreme Pontiff</a>—who possesses the totality of legislative, executive and judicial power in his person,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[224]</a></sup> while particular laws derive formal authority from promulgation by a legislator inferior to the supreme legislator, whether an ordinary or a delegated legislator. The actual subject material of the canons is not just doctrinal or moral in nature, but all-encompassing of the human condition. It has all the ordinary elements of a mature legal system:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clinfocat_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-clinfocat-233">[225]</a></sup> laws, courts, lawyers, judges,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-clinfocat_233-1"><a href="#cite_note-clinfocat-233">[225]</a></sup> a fully articulated <a href="/wiki/1983_Code_of_Canon_Law" title="1983 Code of Canon Law">legal code</a> for the Latin Church<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49-234">[226]</a></sup> as well as a <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">code</a> for the Eastern Catholic Churches,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-Manual_of_Canon_Law,_pg._49-234">[226]</a></sup> principles of <a href="/wiki/Interpretation_(Catholic_canon_law)" title="Interpretation (Catholic canon law)">legal interpretation</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[227]</a></sup> and coercive penalties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[229]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Canon_law_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Canon law of the Catholic Church">Canon law</a> concerns the Catholic Church's life and organisation and is distinct from civil law. In its own field it gives force to civil law only by specific enactment in matters such as the guardianship of minors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[230]</a></sup> Similarly, civil law may give force in its field to canon law, but only by specific enactment, as with regard to canonical marriages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Malta_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-Malta-239">[231]</a></sup> Currently, the <a href="/wiki/1983_Code_of_Canon_Law" title="1983 Code of Canon Law">1983 Code of Canon Law</a> is in effect for the Latin Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[232]</a></sup> The distinct 1990 <i><a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches</a></i> (<i>CCEO</i>, after the Latin initials) applies to the autonomous Eastern Catholic Churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[233]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Latin_and_Eastern_churches">Latin and Eastern churches</span></h3>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Autonomous_particular_churches"></span><span class="anchor" id="Particular_churches_''sui_iuris''"></span>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_particular_churches_and_liturgical_rites" title="Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites">Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Church</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches" title="Eastern Catholic Churches">Eastern Catholic Churches</a></div>

</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">
<a href="/wiki/Armenian_Rite" title="Armenian Rite">Armenian Rite</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Armenian_Catholic_Church" title="Armenian Catholic Church">Armenian</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">
<a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Rite" title="Byzantine Rite">Byzantine Rite</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Albanian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Albanian Greek Catholic Church">Albanian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Belarusian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Belarusian Greek Catholic Church">Belarusian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Bulgarian Greek Catholic Church">Bulgarian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Greek_Catholic_Church_of_Croatia_and_Serbia" title="Greek Catholic Church of Croatia and Serbia">Croatian and Serbian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Greek_Byzantine_Catholic_Church" title="Greek Byzantine Catholic Church">Greek</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Hungarian Greek Catholic Church">Hungarian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Italo-Albanian_Catholic_Church" title="Italo-Albanian Catholic Church">Italo-Albanian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Macedonian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Macedonian Greek Catholic Church">Macedonian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Melkite_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Melkite Greek Catholic Church">Melkite</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Romanian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Romanian Greek Catholic Church">Romanian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Russian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Russian Greek Catholic Church">Russian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ruthenian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church">Ruthenian</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Slovak_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Slovak Greek Catholic Church">Slovak</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Ukrainian</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">
<a href="/wiki/East_Syriac_Rite" title="East Syriac Rite">East Syriac Rite</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
