</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">
<a href="/wiki/Latin_liturgical_rites" title="Latin liturgical rites">Latin liturgical rites</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">
<a href="/wiki/West_Syriac_Rite" title="West Syriac Rite">West Syriac Rite</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Maronite_Church" title="Maronite Church">Maronite</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Syriac_Catholic_Church" title="Syriac Catholic Church">Syriac</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Syro-Malankara_Catholic_Church" title="Syro-Malankara Catholic Church">Syro-Malankara</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism portal</a><br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P_christianity.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/16px-P_christianity.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/24px-P_christianity.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/P_christianity.svg/32px-P_christianity.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Christianity" title="Portal:Christianity">Christianity portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Particular_churches_sui_iuris_sidebar" title="Template:Particular churches sui iuris sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Particular_churches_sui_iuris_sidebar" title="Template talk:Particular churches sui iuris sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Particular_churches_sui_iuris_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In the first thousand years of Catholic history, different varieties of Christianity developed in the Western and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Christian" title="Eastern Christian">Eastern Christian</a> areas of Europe, Asia and Africa. Though most Eastern-tradition churches are no longer in communion with the Catholic Church after the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">Great Schism</a> of 1054 (as well as the earlier <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nestorian_Schism" title="Nestorian Schism">Nestorian Schism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon#Consequences:_Chalcedonian_Schism" title="Council of Chalcedon">Chalcedonian Schism</a>), 23 autonomous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Particular_churches" title="Particular churches">particular churches</a> of eastern traditions participate in the Catholic communion, also known as "churches <i><a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris" title="Sui iuris">sui iuris</a></i>" (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">Latin</a>: <i lang="la">"of one's own right</i>"). The largest and most well known is the Latin Church, the only Western-tradition church, with more than 1 billion members worldwide. Relatively small in terms of adherents compared to the Latin Church, are the 23 self-governing Eastern Catholic Churches with a combined membership of 17.3 million as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roberson_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roberson-242">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gunton_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gunton-243">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[237]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Latin Church is governed by the pope and diocesan bishops directly appointed by him. The pope exercises a direct <a href="/wiki/Patriarch" title="Patriarch">patriarchal</a> role over the Latin Church, which is considered to form the original and still major part of <a href="/wiki/Western_Christianity" title="Western Christianity">Western Christianity</a>, a heritage of certain beliefs and customs originating in Europe and northwestern Africa, some of which are inherited by many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_denominations" title="Christian denominations">Christian denominations</a> that trace their origins to the Protestant Reformation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-west_christ_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-west_christ-246">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Eastern Catholic Churches follow the traditions and spirituality of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christianity</a> and are churches that have always remained in full communion with the Catholic Church or who have chosen to re-enter full communion in the centuries following the <a href="/wiki/East%E2%80%93West_Schism" title="East–West Schism">East–West Schism</a> or earlier divisions. These churches are communities of Catholic Christians whose forms of worship reflect distinct historical and cultural influences rather than differences in doctrine. The pope's recognition of Eastern Catholic Churches, though, has caused controversy in <a href="/wiki/Catholic%E2%80%93Eastern_Orthodox_relations" title="Catholic–Eastern Orthodox relations">ecumenical relations with the Eastern Orthodox</a> and other eastern churches. Historically, pressure to conform to the norms of the Western Christianity practiced by the majority Latin Church led to a degree of encroachment (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liturgical_Latinization" title="Liturgical Latinization">Latinization</a>) on some of the Eastern Catholic traditions. The <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> document, <i><a href="/wiki/Orientalium_Ecclesiarum" title="Orientalium Ecclesiarum">Orientalium Ecclesiarum</a></i>, built on previous reforms to reaffirm the right of Eastern Catholics to maintain their distinct liturgical practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[239]</a></sup>
</p><p>A church <i>sui iuris</i> is defined in the <i><a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">Code of Canons for the Eastern Churches</a></i> as a "group of Christian faithful united by a hierarchy" that is recognised by the pope in his capacity as the <a href="/wiki/Papal_supremacy" title="Papal supremacy">supreme authority</a> on matters of doctrine within the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[240]</a></sup> The term is an innovation of the <i>CCEO</i> to denote the relative autonomy of the Eastern Catholic Churches,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MalankaraCCSIJS_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-MalankaraCCSIJS-249">[241]</a></sup> who remain in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">full communion</a> with the pope, but have governance structures and liturgical traditions separate from that of the Latin Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gunton_243-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gunton-243">[235]</a></sup> While the Latin Church's canons do not explicitly use the term, it is tacitly recognised as equivalent.
</p><p>Some Eastern Catholic churches are governed by a patriarch who is elected by the <a href="/wiki/Synod" title="Synod">synod</a> of the bishops of that church,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCEO55_150_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO55_150-250">[242]</a></sup> others are headed by a <a href="/wiki/Major_archbishop" title="Major archbishop">major archbishop</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCEO151_154_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO151_154-251">[243]</a></sup> others are under a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_bishop" title="Metropolitan bishop">metropolitan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCEO155_173_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO155_173-252">[244]</a></sup> and others are organised as individual <a href="/wiki/Eparchy" title="Eparchy">eparchies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCEO_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO-253">[245]</a></sup> Each church has authority over the particulars of its internal organisation, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgical_rites" title="Catholic liturgical rites">liturgical rites</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_Roman_Calendar" title="General Roman Calendar">liturgical calendar</a> and other aspects of its spirituality, subject only to the authority of the pope.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCEO27_7_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO27_7-254">[246]</a></sup> The Roman Curia has a specific department, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Oriental_Churches" title="Congregation for the Oriental Churches">Congregation for the Oriental Churches</a>, to maintain relations with them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[247]</a></sup> The pope does not generally appoint bishops or clergy in the Eastern Catholic Churches, deferring to their internal governance structures, but may intervene if he feels it necessary.
</p>
<h3><span id="Dioceses.2C_parishes.2C_organisations.2C_and_institutes"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Dioceses,_parishes,_organisations,_and_institutes">Dioceses, parishes, organisations, and institutes</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Catholic_dioceses_(structured_view)" title="List of Catholic dioceses (structured view)">List of Catholic dioceses (structured view)</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parish_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Parish in the Catholic Church">Parish in the Catholic Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religious_institute" title="Religious institute">Religious institute</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_charities" title="Catholic charities">Catholic charities</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:404px;max-width:404px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader"><b>Distribution of Catholics</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[248]</a></sup></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:402px;max-width:402px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="263" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg/400px-Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg/600px-Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg/800px-Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg.png 2x" width="400"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Percentage of Catholics by country (2010)</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:402px;max-width:402px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Number_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="260" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Number_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg/400px-Number_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Number_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg/600px-Number_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Number_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg/800px-Number_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011.svg.png 2x" width="400"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Number of Catholics by country (2010)<br/>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini" style="float:right;font-size:105%;"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholicism_maps" title="Template:Catholicism maps"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Template_talk:Catholicism_maps&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Template talk:Catholicism maps (page does not exist)"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholicism_maps&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Individual countries, regions, or major cities are served by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Particular_church" title="Particular church">particular churches</a> known as <a href="/wiki/Diocese" title="Diocese">dioceses</a> in the Latin Church, or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eparchies" title="Eparchies">eparchies</a> in the Eastern Catholic Churches, each overseen by a bishop. As of 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the Catholic Church has 2,795 dioceses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sees_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-sees-257">[249]</a></sup> The bishops in a particular country are members of a national or regional episcopal conference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>Dioceses are divided into <a href="/wiki/Parish" title="Parish">parishes</a>, each with one or more <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Priesthood_(Catholic_Church)" title="Priesthood (Catholic Church)">priests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deacon" title="Deacon">deacons</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Lay_ecclesial_ministry" title="Lay ecclesial ministry">lay ecclesial ministers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneFaith52_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith52-259">[251]</a></sup> Parishes are responsible for the day to day celebration of the sacraments and pastoral care of the laity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[252]</a></sup> As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are 221,700 parishes worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Latin Church, Catholic men may serve as deacons or priests by receiving sacramental <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Orders" title="Holy Orders">ordination</a>. Men and women may serve as <a href="/wiki/Extraordinary_minister_of_Holy_Communion" title="Extraordinary minister of Holy Communion">extraordinary ministers of Holy Communion</a>, as readers (<a href="/wiki/Reader_(liturgy)" title="Reader (liturgy)">lectors</a>), or as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Altar_servers" title="Altar servers">altar servers</a>. Historically, boys and men have only been permitted to serve as altar servers; however, since the 1990s, girls and women have also been permitted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Apostalicae86_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-Apostalicae86-262">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[note 9]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ordained Catholics, as well as members of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_laity" title="Catholic laity">laity</a>, may enter into <a href="/wiki/Consecrated_life" title="Consecrated life">consecrated life</a> either on an individual basis, as a <a href="/wiki/Hermit" title="Hermit">hermit</a> or <a href="/wiki/Consecrated_virgin" title="Consecrated virgin">consecrated virgin</a>, or by joining an <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_consecrated_life" title="Institute of consecrated life">institute of consecrated life</a> (a religious institute or a <a href="/wiki/Secular_institute" title="Secular institute">secular institute</a>) in which to take <a href="/wiki/Religious_vows" title="Religious vows">vows</a> confirming their desire to follow the three <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_counsels" title="Evangelical counsels">evangelical counsels</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chastity" title="Chastity">chastity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poverty</a> and obedience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canons573-746_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-Canons573-746-264">[255]</a></sup> Examples of institutes of consecrated life are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Order_of_Saint_Benedict" title="Order of Saint Benedict">Benedictines</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Carmelites" title="Carmelites">Carmelites</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominicans</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franciscan" title="Franciscan">Franciscans</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Missionaries_of_Charity" title="Missionaries of Charity">Missionaries of Charity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Legionaries_of_Christ" title="Legionaries of Christ">Legionaries of Christ</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sisters_of_Mercy" title="Sisters of Mercy">Sisters of Mercy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canons573-746_264-1"><a href="#cite_note-Canons573-746-264">[255]</a></sup>
</p><p>"Religious institutes" is a modern term encompassing both "<a href="/wiki/Religious_order_(Catholic)" title="Religious order (Catholic)">religious orders</a>" and "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_congregations" title="Religious congregations">religious congregations</a>," which were once distinguished in <a href="/wiki/Canon_law" title="Canon law">canon law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[256]</a></sup> The terms "religious order" and "religious institute" tend to be used as synonyms colloquially.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[257]</a></sup>
</p><p>By means of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_charities" title="Catholic charities">Catholic charities</a> and beyond, the Catholic Church is the largest non-government provider of <a href="/wiki/Catholic_education" title="Catholic education">education</a> and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_health_care" title="Catholic Church and health care">health care</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geopolitics_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-Geopolitics-22">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Membership">Membership</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">Catholic Church by country</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Christian_denominations_by_number_of_members" title="List of Christian denominations by number of members">List of Christian denominations by number of members</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks hlist"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-top-image"><img alt="Emblem of the Papacy SE.svg" data-file-height="1105" data-file-width="815" decoding="async" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/25px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/38px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/50px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" width="25"/></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle-with-top-image">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Category:Catholic Church by country">a series</a> on the</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Catholic Church by country">Catholic Church by country</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Percent_of_Catholics_by_Country%E2%80%93Pew_Research_2011_(no_legend).svg"><img alt="Distribution of Catholics around the world" data-file-height="263" data-file-width="512" <li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Nauru" title="Catholic Church in Nauru">Nauru</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_New_Zealand" title="Catholic Church in New Zealand">New Zealand</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Palau" title="Catholic Church in Palau">Palau</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Papua_New_Guinea" title="Catholic Church in Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Samoa" title="Catholic Church in Samoa">Samoa</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Solomon_Islands" title="Catholic Church in Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Tonga" title="Catholic Church in Tonga">Tonga</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Tuvalu" title="Catholic Church in Tuvalu">Tuvalu</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Vanuatu" title="Catholic Church in Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Latin_America" title="Catholic Church in Latin America">South America</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Argentina" title="Catholic Church in Argentina">Argentina</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Brazil" title="Catholic Church in Brazil">Brazil</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Chile" title="Catholic Church in Chile">Chile</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Ecuador" title="Catholic Church in Ecuador">Ecuador</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Guyana" title="Catholic Church in Guyana">Guyana</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Paraguay" title="Catholic Church in Paraguay">Paraguay</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Peru" title="Catholic Church in Peru">Peru</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Suriname" title="Catholic Church in Suriname">Suriname</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Uruguay" title="Catholic Church in Uruguay">Uruguay</a></li>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Template:Catholic Church by country"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_Church_by_country" title="Template talk:Catholic Church by country"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_Church_by_country&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table><div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;">
<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:250px; background: white;">
<table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;">

</th></tr><tr>

</tr>
<tr>

<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a></td>
<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:Purple; width:0.8%; overflow: hidden;"> </div></td>

<tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;">
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td>

<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td>
</tr>
</tbody></table>
</div>
</div><p>Catholicism is the second largest <a href="/wiki/Religious_denomination" title="Religious denomination">religious body</a> in the world, surpassed in size only by <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[258]</a></sup> Church membership, defined as baptised Catholics, was 1.345 billion at the end of 2019, which is 18% of the world population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnnuarioPontificio_4-3"><a href="#cite_note-AnnuarioPontificio-4">[4]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> has the largest Catholic population in the world, followed by <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[259]</a></sup> Catholics represent about half of all Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>Geographic distribution of Catholics worldwide continues to shift, with 18.7% in Africa, 48.1% in the Americas, 11.0% Asia, 21.2% in Europe, and 0.8% in Oceania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnnuarioPontificio_4-4"><a href="#cite_note-AnnuarioPontificio-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholic ministers include ordained clergy, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lay_ecclesial_ministers" title="Lay ecclesial ministers">lay ecclesial ministers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Missionary" title="Missionary">missionaries</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catechesis" title="Catechesis">catechists</a>. Also as of the end of 2019, there were 467,938 ordained clergy, including 5,364 bishops, 414,336 priests (diocesan and religious), and 48,238 deacons (permanent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnnuarioPontificio_4-5"><a href="#cite_note-AnnuarioPontificio-4">[4]</a></sup> Non-ordained ministers included 3,157,568 catechists, 367,679 lay missionaries, and 39,951 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lay_ecclesial_ministers" title="Lay ecclesial ministers">lay ecclesial ministers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Catholic_Church_Statistics_2015_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_Church_Statistics_2015-270">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholics who have committed to religious or consecrated life instead of marriage or single celibacy, as a state of life or relational vocation, include 54,559 male religious and 705,529 women religious. These are not ordained, nor generally considered ministers unless also engaged in one of the lay minister categories above.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pontifical_Yearbook_2016-271">[262]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Doctrine">Doctrine</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_theology" title="Catholic theology">Catholic theology</a></div>
<p>Catholic doctrine has developed over the centuries, reflecting direct teachings of early Christians, formal definitions of <a href="/wiki/Heresy_in_Christianity" title="Heresy in Christianity">heretical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Orthodoxy" title="Orthodoxy">orthodox</a> beliefs by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecumenical_councils" title="Ecumenical councils">ecumenical councils</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Papal_bull" title="Papal bull">papal bulls</a>, and theological debate by <a href="/wiki/Scholar" title="Scholar">scholars</a>. The church believes that it is continually guided by the Holy Spirit as it discerns new theological issues and is protected <a href="/wiki/Infallibility_of_the_Church" title="Infallibility of the Church">infallibly</a> from falling into doctrinal error when a firm decision on an issue is reached.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>It teaches that revelation has one common source, <a href="/wiki/God_in_Christianity" title="God in Christianity">God</a>, and two distinct modes of transmission: Sacred Scripture and <a href="/wiki/Sacred_tradition" title="Sacred tradition">Sacred Tradition</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LumenG3_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-LumenG3-275">[266]</a></sup> and that these are authentically interpreted by the <a href="/wiki/Magisterium" title="Magisterium">Magisterium</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[267]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[268]</a></sup> Sacred Scripture consists of the 73 books of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Bible" title="Catholic Bible">Catholic Bible</a>, consisting of 46 <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a> and 27 <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> writings. Sacred Tradition consists of those teachings believed by the church to have been handed down since the time of the Apostles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schreck16_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck16-278">[269]</a></sup> Sacred Scripture and Sacred Tradition are collectively known as the "deposit of faith" (<span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">depositum fidei</i></span> in Latin). These are in turn interpreted by the Magisterium (from <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">magister</i></span>, Latin for "teacher"), the church's teaching authority, which is exercised by the pope and the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Bishops" title="College of Bishops">College of Bishops</a> in union with the pope, the Bishop of Rome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schreck30_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck30-279">[270]</a></sup> Catholic doctrine is authoritatively summarised in the <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i>, published by the Holy See.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cat_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-cat-280">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[272]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nature_of_God">Nature of God</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Trinity" title="Trinity">Trinity</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="568" data-file-width="494" decoding="async" height="253" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg/220px-PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg/330px-PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg/440px-PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PetrusPictaviensis_CottonFaustinaBVII-folio42v_ScutumFidei_early13thc.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>C. 1210 manuscript version of the traditional <a href="/wiki/Shield_of_the_Trinity" title="Shield of the Trinity">Shield of the Trinity</a> theological diagram</div></div></div><p>The Catholic Church holds that there is one <a href="/wiki/Attributes_of_God_in_Christianity#Eternity" title="Attributes of God in Christianity">eternal</a> God, who exists as a <i><a href="/wiki/Perichoresis" title="Perichoresis">perichoresis</a></i> ("mutual indwelling") of three <i><a href="/wiki/Hypostasis_(philosophy_and_religion)" title="Hypostasis (philosophy and religion)">hypostases</a></i>, or "persons": <a href="/wiki/God_the_Father#Christianity" title="God the Father">God the Father</a>; <a href="/wiki/God_the_Son" title="God the Son">God the Son</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Holy_Spirit_in_Christianity" title="Holy Spirit in Christianity">God the Holy Spirit</a>, which together are called the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Trinity" title="Holy Trinity">Holy Trinity</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232_252_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-232_252-282">[273]</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholics believe that Jesus Christ is the "Second Person" of the Trinity, God the Son. In an event known as the <a href="/wiki/Incarnation_(Christianity)" title="Incarnation (Christianity)">Incarnation</a>, through the power of the Holy Spirit, God became united with human nature through the conception of Christ in the womb of the <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">Blessed Virgin Mary</a>. Christ, therefore, is understood as being both fully divine and fully human, including possessing a human <a href="/wiki/Soul" title="Soul">soul</a>. It is taught that Christ's mission on earth included giving people his teachings and providing his example for them to follow as recorded in the four <a href="/wiki/Gospel" title="Gospel">Gospels</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McGrath_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-McGrath-283">[274]</a></sup> Jesus is believed to have remained sinless while on earth, and to have allowed himself to be unjustly executed by <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucifixion</a>, as a sacrifice of himself to reconcile humanity to God; this reconciliation is known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paschal_Mystery" title="Paschal Mystery">Paschal Mystery</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[275]</a></sup> The Greek term "Christ" and the Hebrew "Messiah" both mean "anointed one", referring to the Christian belief that Jesus' death and resurrection are the fulfilment of the Old Testament's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesus_and_messianic_prophecy" title="Jesus and messianic prophecy">messianic prophecies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kreeft71_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft71-285">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Catholic Church teaches dogmatically that "the Holy Spirit proceeds eternally from the Father and the Son, not as from two principles but as from one single principle".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[277]</a></sup> It holds that the Father, as the "principle without principle", is the first origin of the Spirit, but also that he, as Father of the only Son, is with the Son the single principle from which the Spirit proceeds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[278]</a></sup> This belief is expressed in the <span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la"><a href="/wiki/Filioque" title="Filioque">Filioque</a></i></span> clause which was added to the Latin version of the Nicene Creed of 381 but not included in the Greek versions of the creed used in Eastern Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245_248_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-245_248-288">[279]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nature_of_the_church">Nature of the church</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_ecclesiology" title="Catholic ecclesiology">Catholic ecclesiology</a></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that it is the "<a href="/wiki/One_true_church" title="One true church">one true church</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Catholic_News_Service_11-2"><a href="#cite_note-Catholic_News_Service-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[280]</a></sup> "the universal sacrament of salvation for the human race",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GAUDIUM_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-GAUDIUM-290">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-291">[282]</a></sup> and "the one true religion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[283]</a></sup> According to the <i>Catechism</i>, the Catholic Church is further described in the Nicene Creed as the "one, holy, catholic, and apostolic Church".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[284]</a></sup> These are collectively known as the <a href="/wiki/Four_Marks_of_the_Church" title="Four Marks of the Church">Four Marks of the Church</a>. The church teaches that its founder is Jesus Christ.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kreeft98_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft98-294">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter200430_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBokenkotter200430-42">[38]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> records several events considered integral to the establishment of the Catholic Church, including Jesus' activities and teaching and his appointment of the <a href="/wiki/Apostles_in_the_New_Testament" title="Apostles in the New Testament">apostles</a> as witnesses to his ministry, suffering, and resurrection. The <a href="/wiki/Great_Commission" title="Great Commission">Great Commission</a>, after his resurrection, instructed the apostles to continue his work. The coming of the Holy Spirit upon the apostles, in an event known as <a href="/wiki/Pentecost" title="Pentecost">Pentecost</a>, is seen as the beginning of the public ministry of the Catholic Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barry48_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-Barry48-45">[41]</a></sup> The church teaches that all duly consecrated bishops have a lineal succession from the apostles of Christ, known as <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_succession" title="Apostolic succession">apostolic succession</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneFaith46_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith46-295">[286]</a></sup> In particular, the Bishop of Rome (the pope) is considered the successor to the apostle <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Simon_Peter" title="Simon Peter">Simon Peter</a>, a position from which he derives his <a href="/wiki/Papal_supremacy" title="Papal supremacy">supremacy</a> over the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[287]</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholic belief holds that the church "is the continuing presence of Jesus on earth"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schreck131_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck131-297">[288]</a></sup> and that it alone possesses the full means of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Salvation_(Christianity)" title="Salvation (Christianity)">salvation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCC_816_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCC_816-298">[289]</a></sup> Through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Passion_(Christianity)" title="Passion (Christianity)">passion</a> (suffering) of Christ leading to his <a href="/wiki/Crucifixion_of_Jesus" title="Crucifixion of Jesus">crucifixion</a> as described in the Gospels, it is said Christ made himself an oblation to God the Father in order to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atonement_in_Christianity" title="Atonement in Christianity">reconcile</a> humanity to God;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-608_-299">[290]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Resurrection_of_Jesus" title="Resurrection of Jesus">Resurrection of Jesus</a> makes him the firstborn from the dead, the first among many brethren.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[291]</a></sup> By reconciling with God and following Christ's words and deeds, an individual can enter the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_God_(Christianity)" title="Kingdom of God (Christianity)">Kingdom of God</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneFaith26_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith26-301">[292]</a></sup> The church sees its liturgy and sacraments as perpetuating the graces achieved through Christ's sacrifice to strengthen a person's relationship with Christ and aid in overcoming sin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CoCCC_Paschal_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-CoCCC_Paschal-302">[293]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_judgement">Final judgement</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Last_Judgment#Catholicism" title="Last Judgment">Last Judgment § Catholicism</a></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that, immediately after death, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Soul_(spirit)" title="Soul (spirit)">soul</a> of each person will receive a <a href="/wiki/Particular_judgment" title="Particular judgment">particular judgement</a> from God, based on their <a href="/wiki/Sin" title="Sin">sins</a> and their relationship to Christ.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[294]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schreck397_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schreck397-304">[295]</a></sup> This teaching also attests to another day when Christ will sit in universal judgement of all mankind. This <a href="/wiki/Last_Judgment" title="Last Judgment">final judgement</a>, according to the church's teaching, will bring an end to human history and mark the beginning of both a new and better heaven and earth ruled by God in righteousness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[296]</a></sup>
</p><p>Depending on the judgement rendered following death, it is believed that a soul may enter one of three states of the afterlife:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Heaven_in_Christianity#Roman_Catholicism" title="Heaven in Christianity">Heaven</a> is a state of unending union with the divine nature of God, not ontologically, but by grace. It is an eternal life, in which the soul contemplates God in ceaseless <a href="/wiki/Beatific_vision" title="Beatific vision">beatitude</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[297]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Purgatory" title="Purgatory">Purgatory</a> is a temporary condition for the purification of souls who, although destined for Heaven, are not fully detached from sin and thus cannot enter Heaven immediately.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[298]</a></sup> In Purgatory, the soul suffers, and is purged and perfected. Souls in purgatory may be aided in reaching heaven by the prayers of the faithful on earth and by the <a href="/wiki/Intercession_of_saints" title="Intercession of saints">intercession of saints</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[299]</a></sup></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hell_in_Christian_beliefs#Roman_Catholicism" title="Hell in Christian beliefs">Final Damnation</a>: Finally, those who persist in living in a state of mortal sin and do not repent before death subject themselves to hell, an everlasting separation from God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[300]</a></sup> The church teaches that no one is condemned to hell without having freely decided to reject God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[301]</a></sup> No one is <a href="/wiki/Predestination" title="Predestination">predestined</a> to hell and no one can determine with absolute certainty who has been condemned to hell.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[302]</a></sup> Catholicism teaches that through God's mercy a person can repent at any point before death, be illuminated with the truth of the Catholic faith, and thus obtain salvation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Luke23_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-Luke23-312">[303]</a></sup> Some Catholic theologians have speculated that the souls of unbaptised infants and non-Christians without mortal sin but who die in <a href="/wiki/Original_sin" title="Original sin">original sin</a> are assigned to <a href="/wiki/Limbo" title="Limbo">limbo</a>, although this is not an official <a href="/wiki/Dogma_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Dogma in the Catholic Church">dogma</a> of the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[304]</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>While the Catholic Church teaches that it alone possesses the full means of salvation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCC_816_298-1"><a href="#cite_note-CCC_816-298">[289]</a></sup> it also acknowledges that the Holy Spirit can make use of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecclesial_Community" title="Ecclesial Community">Christian communities</a> separated from itself to "impel towards Catholic unity"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ewtn.com_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-ewtn.com-314">[305]</a></sup> and "tend and lead toward the Catholic Church",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ewtn.com_314-1"><a href="#cite_note-ewtn.com-314">[305]</a></sup> and thus bring people to salvation, because these separated communities contain some elements of proper doctrine, albeit admixed with <a href="/wiki/Heresy" title="Heresy">errors</a>. It teaches that anyone who is saved is saved through the Catholic Church but that people can be saved outside of the ordinary means known as <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_desire" title="Baptism of desire">baptism of desire</a>, and by pre-baptismal martyrdom, known as <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_blood" title="Baptism of blood">baptism of blood</a>, as well as when conditions of <a href="/wiki/Invincible_ignorance_(Catholic_theology)" title="Invincible ignorance (Catholic theology)">invincible ignorance</a> are present, although invincible ignorance in itself is not a means of salvation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[306]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Saints_and_devotions">Saints and devotions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">Saint</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canonisation" title="Canonisation">Canonisation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Veneration" title="Veneration">Veneration</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_devotions" title="Catholic devotions">Catholic devotions</a></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Saint" title="Saint">saint</a> (also historically known as a hallow) is a person who is recognised as having an exceptional degree of holiness or likeness or closeness to God, while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canonisation" title="Canonisation">canonisation</a> is the act by which a Christian church declares that a person who has died was a saint, upon which declaration the person is included in the "canon", or list, of recognised saints.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WilsonFischer2005_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-WilsonFischer2005-316">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DiehlDonnelly2001_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-DiehlDonnelly2001-317">[308]</a></sup> The first persons honoured as saints were the <a href="/wiki/Martyr" title="Martyr">martyrs</a>. Pious legends of their deaths were considered affirmations of the truth of their faith in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christ" title="Christ">Christ</a>. By the fourth century, however, "<a href="/wiki/Confessor" title="Confessor">confessors</a>"—people who had confessed their faith not by dying but by word and life—began to be <a href="/wiki/Veneration" title="Veneration">venerated publicly</a>.
</p><p>In the Catholic Church, both in Latin and Eastern Catholic churches, the act of canonisation is reserved to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apostolic_See" title="Apostolic See">Apostolic See</a> and occurs at the conclusion of a long process requiring extensive proof that the candidate for canonisation lived and died in such an exemplary and holy way that he is worthy to be recognised as a saint. The church's official recognition of sanctity implies that the person is now in <a href="/wiki/Heaven" title="Heaven">Heaven</a> and that he may be publicly invoked and mentioned officially in the <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgy</a> of the church, including in the <a href="/wiki/Litany_of_the_Saints" title="Litany of the Saints">Litany of the Saints</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canonisation" title="Canonisation">Canonisation</a> allows universal veneration of the saint in the liturgy of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a>; for permission to venerate merely locally, only <a href="/wiki/Beatification" title="Beatification">beatification</a> is needed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_devotions" title="Catholic devotions">Devotions</a> are "external practices of piety" which are not part of the official liturgy of the Catholic Church but are part of the popular spiritual practices of Catholics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[310]</a></sup> These include various practices regarding the veneration of the saints, especially <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">veneration of the Virgin Mary</a>. Other devotional practices include the <a href="/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross" title="Stations of the Cross">Stations of the Cross</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sacred_Heart" title="Sacred Heart">Sacred Heart</a> of Jesus, the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Face_of_Jesus" title="Holy Face of Jesus">Holy Face of Jesus</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etwndevoti_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-etwndevoti-320">[311]</a></sup> the various <a href="/wiki/Scapular" title="Scapular">scapulars</a>, novenas to various saints,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-popdevos_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-popdevos-321">[312]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">pilgrimages</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[313]</a></sup> and devotions to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eucharist_(Catholic_Church)" title="Eucharist (Catholic Church)">Blessed Sacrament</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-popdevos_321-1"><a href="#cite_note-popdevos-321">[312]</a></sup> and the veneration of <a href="/wiki/Santo_(art)" title="Santo (art)">saintly images</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Santo_(art)" title="Santo (art)"><i>santos</i></a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[314]</a></sup> The bishops at the Second Vatican Council reminded Catholics that "devotions should be so drawn up that they harmonise with the liturgical seasons, accord with the sacred liturgy, are in some fashion derived from it, and lead the people to it, since, in fact, the liturgy by its very nature far surpasses any of them."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[315]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Virgin_Mary">Virgin Mary</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks" style="width:20.0em;"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-top-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg"><img alt="Emblem of the Papacy SE.svg" data-file-height="1105" data-file-width="815" decoding="async" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/25px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/38px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/50px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" width="25"/></a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle-with-top-image">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Roman_Catholic_Mariology" title="Category:Roman Catholic Mariology">a series</a> on the</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Mariology" title="Catholic Mariology">Mariology<br/>of the Roman Catholic Church</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lusenberg-Virgin.jpg" title="Virgo det Josef Moroder"><img alt="Virgo det Josef Moroder" data-file-height="4287" data-file-width="2443" decoding="async" height="263" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Lusenberg-Virgin.jpg/150px-Lusenberg-Virgin.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Lusenberg-Virgin.jpg/225px-Lusenberg-Virgin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Lusenberg-Virgin.jpg/300px-Lusenberg-Virgin.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a><div class="sidebar-caption"><i>Virgo</i> by <a href="/wiki/Josef_Moroder-Lusenberg" title="Josef Moroder-Lusenberg">Josef Moroder-Lusenberg</a></div></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">

<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center; background-color:gold"><a href="/wiki/Marian_feast_days" title="Marian feast days">Key Marian feast days</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content">
