</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Catholic_Mariology_sidebar" title="Template:Catholic Mariology sidebar"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Catholic_Mariology_sidebar" title="Template talk:Catholic Mariology sidebar"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Catholic_Mariology_sidebar&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Mariology of the Catholic Church">Mariology of the Catholic Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_saints" title="Mariology of the saints">Mariology of the saints</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariology_of_the_popes" title="Mariology of the popes">Mariology of the popes</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="618" data-file-width="460" decoding="async" height="296" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG/220px-Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG/330px-Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG/440px-Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Murillo-inmaculada_del_coro-sevilla-mba.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Veneration_of_Mary_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Veneration of Mary in the Catholic Church">Blessed Virgin Mary</a> is highly regarded in the Catholic Church, proclaiming her as <a href="/wiki/Theotokos" title="Theotokos">Mother of God</a>, <a href="/wiki/Immaculate_Conception" title="Immaculate Conception">free from original sin</a> and an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intercessor" title="Intercessor">intercessor</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Catholic_Mariology" title="Catholic Mariology">Catholic Mariology</a> deals with the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Mariology#Dogmatic_teachings" title="Catholic Mariology">dogmas</a> and teachings concerning the life of the <a href="/wiki/Mary,_mother_of_Jesus" title="Mary, mother of Jesus">Mary, mother of Jesus</a>, as well as the veneration of Mary by the faithful. Mary is held in special regard, declared the <a href="/wiki/Theotokos" title="Theotokos">Mother of God</a> (<a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">Θεοτόκος</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek" title="Romanization of Greek">romanized</a>: </small><span title="Greek-language romanization"><i lang="el-Latn">Theotokos</i></span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a> </small>'God-bearer'), and believed as dogma to have remained a <a href="/wiki/Perpetual_virginity_of_Mary" title="Perpetual virginity of Mary">virgin throughout her life</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-325">[316]</a></sup> Further teachings include the doctrines of the <a href="/wiki/Immaculate_Conception" title="Immaculate Conception">Immaculate Conception</a> (her own conception without the stain of original sin) and the <a href="/wiki/Assumption_of_Mary" title="Assumption of Mary">Assumption of Mary</a> (that her body was assumed directly into heaven at the end of her life). Both of these doctrines were defined as infallible dogma, by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_IX" title="Pope Pius IX">Pope Pius IX</a> in 1854 and <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a> in 1950 respectively,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barry,_p._106_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-Barry,_p._106-326">[317]</a></sup> but only after consulting with the Catholic bishops throughout the world to ascertain that this is a Catholic belief.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[318]</a></sup> In the Eastern Catholic churches, however, they continue to celebrate the feast under the name of the <a href="/wiki/Dormition_of_the_Mother_of_God" title="Dormition of the Mother of God">Dormition of the Mother of God</a> on the same date.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[319]</a></sup> The teaching that Mary died before being assumed significantly precedes the idea that she did not. St John Damascene wrote that "St Juvenal, Bishop of Jerusalem, at the Council of Chalcedon (451), made known to the Emperor Marcian and Pulcheria, who wished to possess the body of the Mother of God, that Mary died in the presence of all the Apostles, but that her tomb, when opened, upon the request of St Thomas, was found empty; wherefrom the Apostles concluded that the body was taken up to Heaven."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[320]</a></sup>)
</p><p>Devotions to Mary are part of Catholic piety but are distinct from the worship of God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[321]</a></sup> Practices include prayers and <a href="/wiki/Marian_art_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Marian art in the Catholic Church">Marian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Marian_music" title="Catholic Marian music">music</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Marian_church_buildings" title="Catholic Marian church buildings">architecture</a>. Several liturgical Marian feasts are celebrated throughout the Church Year and she is honoured with many titles such as <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Heaven" title="Queen of Heaven">Queen of Heaven</a>. <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Pope Paul VI</a> called her <a href="/wiki/Mother_of_the_Church" title="Mother of the Church">Mother of the Church</a> because, by giving birth to Christ, she is considered to be the spiritual mother to each member of the <a href="/wiki/Body_of_Christ" title="Body of Christ">Body of Christ</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Barry,_p._106_326-1"><a href="#cite_note-Barry,_p._106-326">[317]</a></sup> Because of her influential role in the life of Jesus, prayers and devotions such as the <a href="/wiki/Hail_Mary" title="Hail Mary">Hail Mary</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rosary" title="Rosary">Rosary</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Salve_Regina" title="Salve Regina">Salve Regina</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Memorare" title="Memorare">Memorare</a> are common Catholic practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[322]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage" title="Christian pilgrimage">Pilgrimage</a> to the sites of several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marian_apparitions" title="Marian apparitions">Marian apparitions</a> affirmed by the church, such as <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Lourdes" title="Our Lady of Lourdes">Lourdes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_F%C3%A1tima" title="Our Lady of Fátima">Fátima</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Guadalupe" title="Our Lady of Guadalupe">Guadalupe</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[323]</a></sup> are also popular Catholic devotions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[324]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments">Sacraments</span></h2>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Celebration_of_the_sacraments"></span><span class="anchor" id="Doctrine_of_the_sacraments"></span>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">Sacraments of the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1102" data-file-width="1543" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg/220px-Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg/330px-Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg/440px-Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mass_at_Lourdes.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mass at the Grotto at <a href="/wiki/Lourdes" title="Lourdes">Lourdes</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chalice" title="Chalice">chalice</a> is displayed to the people immediately after the consecration of the wine.</div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that it was entrusted with <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Sacraments of the Catholic Church">seven sacraments</a> that were instituted by Christ. The number and nature of the sacraments were defined by several <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_council" title="Ecumenical council">ecumenical councils</a>, most recently the Council of Trent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1113_14_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-1113_14-334">[325]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[note 10]</a></sup> These are <a href="/wiki/Baptism" title="Baptism">Baptism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Confirmation" title="Confirmation">Confirmation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance_(Catholic_Church)" title="Sacrament of Penance (Catholic Church)">Penance</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anointing_of_the_Sick_(Catholic_Church)" title="Anointing of the Sick (Catholic Church)">Anointing of the Sick</a> (formerly called Extreme Unction, one of the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Last_Rites" title="Last Rites">Last Rites</a>"), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Orders" title="Holy Orders">Holy Orders</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_marriage" title="Catholic marriage">Holy Matrimony</a>. Sacraments are visible rituals that Catholics see as signs of God's presence and effective channels of God's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grace_(Christianity)" title="Grace (Christianity)">grace</a> to all those who receive them with the proper disposition (<i><a href="/wiki/Ex_opere_operato" title="Ex opere operato">ex opere operato</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[326]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Catechism_of_the_Catholic_Church" title="Catechism of the Catholic Church">Catechism of the Catholic Church</a></i> categorises the sacraments into three groups, the "sacraments of Christian initiation", "sacraments of healing" and "sacraments at the service of communion and the mission of the faithful". These groups broadly reflect the stages of people's natural and spiritual lives which each sacrament is intended to serve.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[327]</a></sup>
</p><p>The liturgies of the sacraments are central to the church's mission. According to the <i>Catechism</i>:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>In the liturgy of the New Covenant every liturgical action, especially the celebration of the Eucharist and the sacraments, is an encounter between Christ and the Church. The liturgical assembly derives its unity from the "communion of the Holy Spirit" who gathers the children of God into the one Body of Christ. This assembly transcends racial, cultural, social—indeed, all human affinities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[328]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>According to church doctrine, the sacraments of the church require the proper form, matter, and intent to be validly celebrated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[329]</a></sup> In addition, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canon_Law" title="Canon Law">Canon Laws</a> for both the Latin Church and the Eastern Catholic Churches govern who may licitly celebrate certain sacraments, as well as strict rules about who may receive the sacraments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CoCC291_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-CoCC291-340">[330]</a></sup> Notably, because the church teaches that Christ is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_presence#Catholic_and_Orthodox" title="Real presence">present</a> in the Eucharist,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kreeft326_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft326-341">[331]</a></sup> those who are conscious of being in a state of mortal sin are forbidden to receive the sacrament until they have received absolution through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Reconciliation" title="Sacrament of Reconciliation">sacrament of Reconciliation</a> (Penance).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kreeft331_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft331-342">[332]</a></sup> Catholics are normally obliged to abstain from eating for at least an hour before receiving the sacrament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kreeft331_342-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft331-342">[332]</a></sup> Non-Catholics are ordinarily prohibited from receiving the Eucharist as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CoCC291_340-1"><a href="#cite_note-CoCC291-340">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[333]</a></sup>
</p><p>Catholics, even if they were in danger of death and unable to approach a Catholic minister, may not ask for the sacraments of the Eucharist, penance or anointing of the sick from someone, such as a Protestant minister, who is not known to be validly ordained in line with Catholic teaching on ordination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[335]</a></sup> Likewise, even in grave and pressing need, Catholic ministers may not administer these sacraments to those who do not manifest Catholic faith in the sacrament. In relation to the churches of Eastern Christianity not in communion with the Holy See, the Catholic Church is less restrictive, declaring that "a certain <i>communion in sacris</i>, and so in the Eucharist, given suitable circumstances and the approval of Church authority, is not merely possible but is encouraged."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[336]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments_of_initiation">Sacraments of initiation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sacraments_of_initiation" title="Sacraments of initiation">Sacraments of initiation</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Baptism">Baptism</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2197" data-file-width="2470" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg/220px-Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg/330px-Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg/440px-Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bapt%C3%AAme_Cath%C3%A9drale_de_Troyes_290308.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Baptism of <a href="/wiki/Augustine_of_Hippo" title="Augustine of Hippo">Augustine of Hippo</a> as represented in a sculptural group in <a href="/wiki/Troyes_Cathedral" title="Troyes Cathedral">Troyes Cathedral</a> (1549), <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a></div></div></div>
<p>As viewed by the Catholic Church, Baptism is the first of three sacraments of initiation as a Christian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[337]</a></sup> It washes away all sins, both <a href="/wiki/Original_sin" title="Original sin">original sin</a> and personal actual sins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[338]</a></sup> It makes a person a member of the church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[339]</a></sup> As a gratuitous gift of God that requires no merit on the part of the person who is baptised, it is <a href="/wiki/Infant_baptism" title="Infant baptism">conferred even on children</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[340]</a></sup> who, though they have no personal sins, need it on account of original sin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[341]</a></sup> If a new-born child is in a danger of death, anyone—be it a doctor, a nurse, or a parent—may baptise the child.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[342]</a></sup> Baptism marks a person permanently and cannot be repeated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[343]</a></sup> The Catholic Church recognises as valid baptisms conferred even by people who are not Catholics or Christians, provided that they intend to baptise ("to do what the Church does when she baptises") and that they use the <a href="/wiki/Trinitarian_formula#Use_in_baptism" title="Trinitarian formula">Trinitarian baptismal formula</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[344]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Confirmation">Confirmation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Confirmation_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Confirmation in the Catholic Church">Confirmation in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<p>The Catholic Church sees the sacrament of confirmation as required to complete the grace given in baptism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[345]</a></sup> When adults are baptised, confirmation is normally given immediately afterwards,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cann883_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-cann883-356">[346]</a></sup> a practice followed even with newly baptised infants in the Eastern Catholic Churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cceo695_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-cceo695-357">[347]</a></sup> In the West confirmation of children is delayed until they are old enough to understand or at the bishop's discretion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cann891_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-cann891-358">[348]</a></sup> In Western Christianity, particularly Catholicism, the sacrament is called <i>confirmation</i>, because it confirms and strengthens the grace of baptism; in the Eastern Churches, it is called <i>chrismation</i>, because the essential rite is the anointing of the person with <a href="/wiki/Chrism" title="Chrism">chrism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chrism_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chrism-359">[349]</a></sup> a mixture of <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a> and some perfumed substance, usually <a href="/wiki/Oleoresin" title="Oleoresin">balsam</a>, blessed by a bishop.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chrism_359-1"><a href="#cite_note-Chrism-359">[349]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[350]</a></sup> Those who receive confirmation must be in a state of grace, which for those who have reached the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Age_of_reason_(canon_law)" title="Age of reason (canon law)">age of reason</a> means that they should first be cleansed spiritually by the sacrament of Penance; they should also have the intention of receiving the sacrament, and be prepared to show in their lives that they are Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[351]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Eucharist">Eucharist</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Eucharist_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Eucharist in the Catholic Church">Eucharist in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BentoXVI-51-11052007_(frag).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="550" data-file-width="416" decoding="async" height="291" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg/220px-BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg/330px-BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/BentoXVI-51-11052007_%28frag%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BentoXVI-51-11052007_(frag).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a> celebrates the Eucharist at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canonisation" title="Canonisation">canonisation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Frei_Galv%C3%A3o" title="Frei Galvão">Frei Galvão</a> in <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo" title="São Paulo">São Paulo</a>, Brazil on 11 May 2007</div></div></div>
<p>For Catholics, the Eucharist is the sacrament which completes Christian initiation. It is described as "the source and summit of the Christian life".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[352]</a></sup> The ceremony in which a Catholic first receives the Eucharist is known as <a href="/wiki/First_Communion" title="First Communion">First Communion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[353]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Eucharistic celebration, also called the <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)" title="Mass (liturgy)">Mass</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Divine_liturgy" title="Divine liturgy">Divine liturgy</a>, includes prayers and scriptural readings, as well as an offering of bread and wine, which are brought to the <a href="/wiki/Altar" title="Altar">altar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consecration#Eucharist" title="Consecration">consecrated</a> by the priest to become the body and the blood of Jesus Christ, a change called <a href="/wiki/Transubstantiation" title="Transubstantiation">transubstantiation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[354]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[note 11]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Words_of_consecration" title="Words of consecration">words of consecration</a> reflect the words spoken by Jesus during the <a href="/wiki/Last_Supper" title="Last Supper">Last Supper</a>, where Christ offered his body and blood to his Apostles the night before his crucifixion. The sacrament re-presents (makes present) the sacrifice of Jesus on the cross,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[355]</a></sup> and perpetuates it. Christ's death and resurrection give grace through the sacrament that unites the faithful with Christ and one another, remits venial sin, and aids against committing moral sin (though mortal sin itself is forgiven through the sacrament of penance).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ccc1392_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-ccc1392-367">[356]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3872" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg/170px-Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg/255px-Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg/340px-Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Convento_de_San_Francisco_-_Ciudad_de_M%C3%A9xico_-_Creyente.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Catholic believer prays in a church in <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments_of_healing">Sacraments of healing</span></h3>
<p>The two sacraments of healing are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance_(Catholic_Church)" title="Sacrament of Penance (Catholic Church)">Sacrament of Penance</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anointing_of_the_Sick_(Catholic_Church)" title="Anointing of the Sick (Catholic Church)">Anointing of the Sick</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Penance">Penance</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance" title="Sacrament of Penance">Sacrament of Penance</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Sacrament_of_Penance" title="Sacrament of Penance">Sacrament of Penance</a> (also called Reconciliation, Forgiveness, Confession, and Conversion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[357]</a></sup>) exists for the conversion of those who, after baptism, separate themselves from Christ by sin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[358]</a></sup> Essential to this sacrament are acts both by the sinner (examination of conscience, contrition with a determination not to sin again, confession to a priest, and performance of some act to repair the damage caused by sin) and by the priest (determination of the act of reparation to be performed and <a href="/wiki/Absolution" title="Absolution">absolution</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[359]</a></sup> Serious sins (<a href="/wiki/Mortal_sin" title="Mortal sin">mortal sins</a>) should be confessed at least once a year and always before receiving Holy Communion, while confession of <a href="/wiki/Venial_sin" title="Venial sin">venial sins</a> also is recommended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[360]</a></sup> The priest is bound under the severest penalties to maintain the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seal_of_confession" title="Seal of confession">seal of confession</a>", absolute secrecy about any sins revealed to him in confession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[361]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Anointing_of_the_sick">Anointing of the sick</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anointing_of_the_Sick_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Anointing of the Sick in the Catholic Church">Anointing of the Sick in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:243px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Extreme_Unction_Rogier_Van_der_Weyden.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="254" data-file-width="241" decoding="async" height="254" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ae/Extreme_Unction_Rogier_Van_der_Weyden.jpg" width="241"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Extreme_Unction_Rogier_Van_der_Weyden.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Seven_Sacraments_Altarpiece" title="Seven Sacraments Altarpiece">Seven Sacraments Altarpiece</a> <a href="/wiki/Triptych" title="Triptych">triptych</a> painting of Extreme Unction (Anointing of the Sick) with oil being administered by a priest during last rites. <a href="/wiki/Rogier_van_der_Weyden" title="Rogier van der Weyden">Rogier van der Weyden</a>, c. 1445.</div></div></div>
<p>While chrism is used only for the three sacraments that cannot be repeated, a different oil is used by a priest or bishop to bless a Catholic who, because of illness or old age, has begun to be in danger of death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[362]</a></sup> This sacrament, known as Anointing of the Sick, is believed to give comfort, peace, courage and, if the sick person is unable to make a confession, even forgiveness of sins.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>The sacrament is also referred to as <i>Unction</i>, and in the past as <i>Extreme Unction</i>, and it is one of the three sacraments that constitute the <a href="/wiki/Last_rites" title="Last rites">last rites</a>, together with Penance and <a href="/wiki/Viaticum" title="Viaticum">Viaticum</a> (Eucharist).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[364]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sacraments_at_the_service_of_communion">Sacraments at the service of communion</span></h3>
<p>According to the Catechism, there are two sacraments of <a href="/wiki/Koinonia" title="Koinonia">communion</a> directed towards the salvation of others: priesthood and marriage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[365]</a></sup> Within the general vocation to be a Christian, these two sacraments "consecrate to specific mission or <a href="/wiki/Vocation" title="Vocation">vocation</a> among the people of God. Men receive the holy orders to feed the Church by the word and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grace_(Christianity)" title="Grace (Christianity)">grace</a>. Spouses marry so that their love may be fortified to fulfil duties of their state".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Holy_Orders">Holy Orders</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Holy_orders_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Holy orders in the Catholic Church">Holy orders in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1389" data-file-width="2084" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg/220px-Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg/330px-Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg/440px-Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Priesterweihe_in_Schwyz_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Priests lay their hands on the ordinands during the rite of ordination.</div></div></div>
<p>The sacrament of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holy_Orders_(Catholic_Church)" title="Holy Orders (Catholic Church)">Holy Orders</a> consecrates and deputes some Christians to serve the whole body as members of three degrees or orders: episcopate (bishops), presbyterate (priests) and diaconate (deacons).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cann10081009_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-cann10081009-378">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[368]</a></sup> The church has defined rules on who may be ordained into the <a href="/wiki/Clergy#Catholicism" title="Clergy">clergy</a>. In the Latin Church, the priesthood is generally restricted to celibate men, and the episcopate is always restricted to celibate men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[369]</a></sup> Men who are already married may be ordained in certain Eastern Catholic churches in most countries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[370]</a></sup> and the personal ordinariates and may become deacons even in the Western Church<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCL1031_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCL1031-382">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCL1037_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCL1037-383">[372]</a></sup> (see <a href="/wiki/Clerical_marriage" title="Clerical marriage">Clerical marriage</a>). But after becoming a Catholic priest, a man may not marry (see <a href="/wiki/Clerical_celibacy" title="Clerical celibacy">Clerical celibacy</a>) unless he is formally laicised.
</p><p>All clergy, whether deacons, priests or bishops, may preach, teach, baptise, witness marriages and conduct funeral liturgies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[373]</a></sup> Only bishops and priests can administer the sacraments of the Eucharist, Reconciliation (Penance) and Anointing of the Sick.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[374]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[375]</a></sup> Only bishops can administer the sacrament of Holy Orders, which <a href="/wiki/Ordination" title="Ordination">ordains</a> someone into the clergy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneFaith114_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneFaith114-387">[376]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Matrimony">Matrimony</span></h4>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Sacrament_of_marriage"></span>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Marriage in the Catholic Church">Marriage in the Catholic Church</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_teachings_on_sexual_morality" title="Catholic teachings on sexual morality">Catholic teachings on sexual morality</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG/220px-Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG/330px-Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG/440px-Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jf9694Wedding_San_Nicolas_Church_Tolentine_Marriage_Pampangafvf_02.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Wedding mass in the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Catholic Church teaches that marriage is a social and spiritual bond between a man and a woman, ordered towards the good of the spouses and procreation of children; according to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_teachings_on_sexual_morality" title="Catholic teachings on sexual morality">Catholic teachings on sexual morality</a>, it is the only appropriate context for sexual activity. A Catholic marriage, or any marriage between baptised individuals of any Christian denomination, is viewed as a sacrament. A sacramental marriage, once consummated, cannot be dissolved except by death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[note 12]</a></sup> The church recognises certain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marriage_(Catholic_Church)#Conditions_for_a_valid_marriage_of_Catholics" title="Marriage (Catholic Church)">conditions</a>, such as freedom of consent, as required for any marriage to be valid; In addition, the church sets specific rules and norms, known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marriage_(Catholic_Church)#Canonical_form" title="Marriage (Catholic Church)">canonical form</a>, that Catholics must follow.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>The church does not recognise divorce as ending a valid marriage and allows state-recognised divorce only as a means of protecting the property and well-being of the spouses and any children. However, consideration of particular cases by the competent ecclesiastical tribunal can lead to declaration of the invalidity of a marriage, a declaration usually referred to as an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annulment_(Catholic_Church)" title="Annulment (Catholic Church)">annulment</a>. Remarriage following a divorce is not permitted unless the prior marriage was declared invalid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[381]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Liturgy">Liturgy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgy" title="Catholic liturgy">Catholic liturgy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thebible33.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Thebible33.jpg/220px-Thebible33.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Thebible33.jpg/330px-Thebible33.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Thebible33.jpg/440px-Thebible33.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thebible33.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Catholic religious objects – <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Holy Bible</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crucifix" title="Crucifix">crucifix</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rosary" title="Rosary">rosary</a></div></div></div>
<p>Among the 24 autonomous (<i><a href="/wiki/Sui_iuris" title="Sui iuris">sui iuris</a></i>) churches, numerous liturgical and other traditions exist, called rites, which reflect historical and cultural diversity rather than differences in belief.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[382]</a></sup> In the definition of the <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Canons_of_the_Eastern_Churches" title="Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches">Code of Canons of the Eastern Churches</a>, "a rite is the liturgical, theological, spiritual, and disciplinary patrimony, culture and circumstances of history of a distinct people, by which its own manner of living the faith is manifested in each Church <i>sui iuris</i>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCEO28_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCEO28-395">[383]</a></sup>
</p><p>The liturgy of the sacrament of the <a href="/wiki/Eucharist" title="Eucharist">Eucharist</a>, called the <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)" title="Mass (liturgy)">Mass</a> in the West and <a href="/wiki/Divine_Liturgy" title="Divine Liturgy">Divine Liturgy</a> or other names in the East, is the principal liturgy of the Catholic Church.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[384]</a></sup> This is because it is considered the propitiatory sacrifice of Christ himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[385]</a></sup> Its most widely used form is that of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a> as promulgated by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Paul_VI" title="Pope Paul VI">Paul VI</a> in 1969 and revised by <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II" title="Pope John Paul II">Pope John Paul II</a> in 2002. In certain circumstances, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1962_Roman_Missal" title="1962 Roman Missal">1962 form</a> of the Roman Rite remains authorised in the Latin Church. Eastern Catholic Churches have their own rites. The liturgies of the Eucharist and the other sacraments vary from rite to rite, reflecting different theological emphases.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_rites">Western rites</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Latin_liturgical_rites" title="Latin liturgical rites">Latin liturgical rites</a></div>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Roman_Rite_of_Mass"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></p><table class="sidebar nomobile nowraplinks"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg"><img alt="Emblem of the Papacy SE.svg" data-file-height="1105" data-file-width="815" C. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liturgy_of_the_Eucharist" title="Liturgy of the Eucharist">Liturgy of the Eucharist</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<ul><li><small><i>See also: <a href="/wiki/Eucharist_in_the_Catholic_Church" title="Eucharist in the Catholic Church">Eucharist in the Catholic Church</a></i></small></li></ul>
<dl><dd><a href="/wiki/Offertory" title="Offertory">Preparation of the gifts</a></dd>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Offertory" title="Offertory">Prayer over the offerings</a></dd>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Anaphora_(liturgy)" title="Anaphora (liturgy)">Eucharistic Prayer</a></dd>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Mass_in_the_Catholic_Church#Communion_rite" title="Mass in the Catholic Church">Communion rite</a>:</dd>
<dd><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Lord%E2%80%99s_Prayer" title="The Lord’s Prayer">The Lord’s Prayer</a></dd>
<dd>Rite of peace</dd>
<dd><a href="/wiki/Mass_in_the_Catholic_Church#Communion_rite" title="Mass in the Catholic Church">Fraction</a></dd>
<dd>Reception of Communion</dd></dl></td>
</tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">
D. <a href="/wiki/Mass_(liturgy)#Concluding_rite" title="Mass (liturgy)">Concluding rites</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content hlist">
<i>"<a href="/wiki/Ite,_missa_est" title="Ite, missa est">Ite, missa est</a>!"</i></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below">
<a class="image" href="/wiki/File:046CupolaSPietro.jpg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/16px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/24px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/046CupolaSPietro.jpg/32px-046CupolaSPietro.jpg 2x" width="16"/></a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:Catholicism" title="Portal:Catholicism">Catholicism portal</a></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Roman_Rite_of_Mass" title="Template:Roman Rite of Mass"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Roman_Rite_of_Mass" title="Template talk:Roman Rite of Mass"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Roman_Rite_of_Mass&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Rite" title="Roman Rite">Roman Rite</a> is the most common <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic_liturgical_rites" title="Catholic liturgical rites">rite of worship</a> used by the Catholic Church, with the <a href="/wiki/Mass_of_Paul_VI" title="Mass of Paul VI">Ordinary Form of the Roman Rite</a> form of the Mass. Its use is found worldwide, originating in Rome and spreading throughout Europe, influencing and eventually supplanting local rites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[386]</a></sup> The present ordinary form of Mass in the Roman Rite, found in the post-1969 editions of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Missal" title="Roman Missal">Roman Missal</a>, is usually celebrated in the local <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">vernacular</a> language, using an officially approved translation from the original text in <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>. An outline of its major liturgical elements can be found in the sidebar.
</p><p>In 2007, Pope Benedict XVI affirmed the licitness of continued use of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1962_Roman_Missal" title="1962 Roman Missal">1962 Roman Missal</a> as an "extraordinary form" (<i>forma extraordinaria</i>) of the Roman Rite, speaking of it also as an <i>usus antiquior</i> ("older use"), and issuing new more permissive norms for its employment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[387]</a></sup> An instruction issued four years later spoke of the two forms or usages of the Roman Rite approved by the pope as the ordinary form and the extraordinary form ("the <i>forma ordinaria</i>" and "the <i>forma extraordinaria</i>").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Universae_Ecclesiae_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-Universae_Ecclesiae-400">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1962 edition of the Roman Missal, published a few months before the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Second Vatican Council</a> opened, was the last that presented the Mass as standardised in 1570 by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_V" title="Pope Pius V">Pope Pius V</a> at the request of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Trent" title="Council of Trent">Council of Trent</a> and that is therefore known as the Tridentine Mass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kreeft326_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kreeft326-341">[331]</a></sup> Pope Pius V's Roman Missal was subjected to minor revisions by <a href="/wiki/Pope_Clement_VIII" title="Pope Clement VIII">Pope Clement VIII</a> in 1604, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_VIII" title="Pope Urban VIII">Pope Urban VIII</a> in 1634, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_X" title="Pope Pius X">Pope Pius X</a> in 1911, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Pius_XII" title="Pope Pius XII">Pope Pius XII</a> in 1955, and <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII" title="Pope John XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a> in 1962. Each successive edition was the ordinary form of the Roman Rite Mass until superseded by a later edition. When the 1962 edition was superseded by that of Paul VI, promulgated in 1969, its continued use at first required permission from bishops;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[389]</a></sup> but <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a>'s 2007 <a href="/wiki/Motu_proprio" title="Motu proprio">motu proprio</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Summorum_Pontificum" title="Summorum Pontificum">Summorum Pontificum</a></i> allowed free use of it for Mass celebrated without a congregation and authorised parish priests to permit, under certain conditions, its use even at public Masses. Except for the scriptural readings, which Pope Benedict allowed to be proclaimed in the vernacular language, it is celebrated exclusively in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liturgical_Latin" title="Liturgical Latin">liturgical Latin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[390]</a></sup> These permissions were largely removed by Pope Francis in 2021, who issued the <i>motu proprio</i> <i><a href="/wiki/Traditionis_custodes" title="Traditionis custodes">Traditionis custodes</a></i> in order to emphasize the Ordinary Form as promulgated by Popes Paul VI and John Paul II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MPTC_206-1"><a href="#cite_note-MPTC-206">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2014, clergy in the small <a href="/wiki/Personal_ordinariate" title="Personal ordinariate">personal ordinariates</a> set up for groups of former Anglicans under the terms of the 2009 document <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglicanorum_Coetibus" title="Anglicanorum Coetibus">Anglicanorum Coetibus</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anglicanorum_Coetibus_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anglicanorum_Coetibus-403">[391]</a></sup> are permitted to use a variation of the Roman Rite called "Divine Worship" or, less formally, "Ordinariate Use",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[392]</a></sup> which incorporates elements of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglican_liturgy" title="Anglican liturgy">Anglican liturgy</a> and traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[note 13]</a></sup> an accommodation protested by Anglican leaders.
</p><p>In the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Milan" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milan">Archdiocese of Milan</a>, with around five million Catholics the largest in Europe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[393]</a></sup> Mass is celebrated according to the <a href="/wiki/Ambrosian_Rite" title="Ambrosian Rite">Ambrosian Rite</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Latin_liturgical_rites" title="Latin liturgical rites">Latin Church rites</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Mozarabic_Rite" title="Mozarabic Rite">Mozarabic</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[394]</a></sup> and those of some religious institutes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[395]</a></sup> These liturgical rites have an antiquity of at least 200 years before 1570, the date of Pope Pius V's <i><a href="/wiki/Quo_primum" title="Quo primum">Quo primum</a></i>, and were thus allowed to continue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[396]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Eastern_rites">Eastern rites</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Catholic_particular_churches_and_liturgical_rites#Eastern_rites" title="Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites">Catholic particular churches and liturgical rites § Eastern rites</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3684" data-file-width="4834" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg/220px-Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg/330px-Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg/440px-Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Crowning_in_Syro-Malabar_Nasrani_Wedding_by_Mar_Gregory_Karotemprel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_Syrian_Rite" title="East Syrian Rite">East Syrian Rite</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wedding_crowning" title="Wedding crowning">wedding crowning</a> celebrated by a bishop of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syro-Malabar_Catholic_Church" title="Syro-Malabar Catholic Church">Syro-Malabar Catholic Church</a> in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, one of the 23 Eastern Catholic Churches in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">full communion</a> with the pope and the Catholic Church.</div></div></div>
<p>The Eastern Catholic Churches share common patrimony and liturgical rites as their counterparts, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> and other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Christian" title="Eastern Christian">Eastern Christian</a> churches who are no longer in communion with the Holy See. These include churches that historically developed in Russia, Caucasus, the Balkans, North Eastern Africa, India and the Middle East. The Eastern Catholic Churches are groups of faithful who have either never been out of communion with the Holy See or who have restored communion with it at the cost of breaking communion with their associates of the same tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[397]</a></sup>
</p><p>The rites used by the Eastern Catholic Churches include the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Rite" title="Byzantine Rite">Byzantine Rite</a>, in its Antiochian, Greek and Slavonic varieties; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alexandrian_Rite" title="Alexandrian Rite">Alexandrian Rite</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Syrian_Rite" title="West Syrian Rite">Syriac Rite</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Rite" title="Armenian Rite">Armenian Rite</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Maronite_Rite" title="Maronite Rite">Maronite Rite</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chaldean_Rite" title="Chaldean Rite">Chaldean Rite</a>. Eastern Catholic Churches have the autonomy to set the particulars of their liturgical forms and worship, within certain limits to protect the "accurate observance" of their liturgical tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[398]</a></sup> In the past some of the rites used by the Eastern Catholic Churches were subject to a degree of <a href="/wiki/Liturgical_Latinisation" title="Liturgical Latinisation">liturgical Latinisation</a>. However, in recent years Eastern Catholic Churches have returned to traditional Eastern practices in accord with the <a href="/wiki/Second_Vatican_Council" title="Second Vatican Council">Vatican II</a> decree <i><a href="/wiki/Orientalium_Ecclesiarum" title="Orientalium Ecclesiarum">Orientalium Ecclesiarum</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[399]</a></sup> Each church has its own <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liturgical_calendar" title="Liturgical calendar">liturgical calendar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[400]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_and_cultural_issues"><span class="anchor" id="Social_and_cultural_issues"></span><span class="anchor" id="Social,_environmental_and_cultural_issues"></span>Social and cultural issues</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1045330069" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="sidebar sidebar-collapse nomobile nowraplinks plainlist"><tbody><tr><td class="sidebar-pretitle">Part of <a href="/wiki/Category:Catholic_social_teaching" title="Category:Catholic social teaching">a series</a> on</td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-title-with-pretitle"><a href="/wiki/Catholic_social_teaching" title="Catholic social teaching">Catholic social teaching</a></th></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-image"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg"><img alt="Emblem of the Holy See" data-file-height="1105" data-file-width="815" decoding="async" height="102" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/75px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/113px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg/150px-Emblem_of_the_Papacy_SE.svg.png 2x" width="75"/></a><div class="sidebar-caption"><span style="font-size:85%;"><a href="/wiki/Emblem" title="Emblem">Emblem</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a></span></div></td></tr><tr><th class="sidebar-heading" style="background-color:gold">
